PARA.TAB: Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr G.B. Nehl) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government, the Hon. Warwick Smith, will be absent from question time today. Mr Smith is in Melbourne on government business. The Minister for Administrative Services, the Hon. David Jull, will answer questions on his behalf.

—My question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister. Has the Acting Prime Minister's attention been drawn to comments today by Westpac's chief economist Bill Evans that unemployment may rise to nine per cent by the end of the year and they are forecasting 8¾ per cent? Is it also not the case that we now have the forecasters for Westpac and the government's own Treasury advisers last night at Senate estimates saying that neither the budget nor the government's industrial relations policy will have any favourable impact on employment? When will this government change strategy to give priority to jobs for Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had my attention drawn to a related matter. Today the ACCI and Westpac released the September quarter survey of manufacturers. It reported that a survey of industrial trends, the first national survey entirely conducted after the bringing down of the 1996 budget, shows a marked rise in business expectations for the next six months. To quote Mark Paterson, `Business confidence is higher than at any time during last year.' Manufacturers, again, predicted increased new orders and output for the December quarter. The outlook for profits is positive.

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, it follows that the upswing in confidence and upswing in profits will engender more jobs as part of that process. I note further that a net balance of 16 per cent of respondents expected an upturn in new orders in the coming quarter.

TALK.START.PARA: —With a huge rise in unemployment.

—You have to look at the trend lines. You have been around long enough in your past incarnations—and some would say too long. If you look at that you will see that that is a doubling of respondents saying that they expect an upturn in new orders in the coming quarter. In other words, there are parts that you have selectively quoted. I simply say that the government's budget settings will put the right framework in place to create jobs. The sooner you pass our industrial relations reform legislation that will help as well.
—I ask the Acting Prime Minister to table the document from which he was quoting.
—No, the document is confidential.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Given the recent easing of the interest rate burden on Australian families and small business, can the Treasurer advise the House what the implications would be for continued low interest rates if the government's savings measures were blocked by the Senate? What would be the effect on average Australian families and battling small business if this was to occur?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Australians are already experiencing a down payment on this government's good fiscal management. Financial markets responded positively to my announcement on 12 March of fiscal tightening. The sentiment was confirmed when the budget was delivered. Variable rate housing loans from banks have fallen from 10.5 per cent at the end of May to 9.25 per cent at the end of August—a money in the bank delivery to home buyers in Australia, a drop in rates from 10.5 per cent at the end of May to 9.25 per cent at the end of August.

ANSWER.PARA: Over the same period variable rate mortgage managers have seen rates go down from 8.9 per cent to 8.5 per cent. Indicator rates for variable loans to small business fell by 0.5 of a percentage point during August. The indicator rate for three‐year fixed small business loans has fallen from 10.1 per cent at the end of May to 9.1 per cent at the end of August. This is a government that by confronting the big issues of the Australian economy has been able to direct benefits to Australian small businesses and to Australian home buyers.

You just heard the Acting Prime Minister indicate the strength of the ACCI‐Westpac report showing that net respondents—that is, those going one way over those going the other way—are expecting an improvement in business conditions in the next six months. A net balance of 16 per cent of respondents expect an upturn in new orders in the coming quarter—up from eight per cent in the previous quarter. A net balance of seven per cent predict increased output in the December quarter. The net balance of respondents planning to increase spending on plant and equipment in the next 12 months was up eight per cent. A net balance of 28 per cent of respondents expect higher profits in the next 12 months.

When we hear the opposition talking about unemployment, we remember those years when the Labor Party ran unemployment in double figures. Now there is the fantastic notion coming from the Labor Party that if only we increased our deficits and debt that would make a difference. The Labor Party left an unemployment rate of 8½ per cent plus after running up $70 billion of cumulated deficits. If cumulating deficits could have solved unemployment you would have been the champions, but you still had unemployment over eight per cent, coming off double figures, on $70 billion of deficit. That is a record of failure, but this is an opposition that has not learned. It is still persisting with the fantastic notion that running up further debt would make inroads in relation to unemployment.

The way to deal with unemployment in this country and deal with it permanently is to set Australia on a path for sustainable growth, to set a path for low interest rates, to set a path for business confidence, to set a path for a flexible labour market and to deal with all of those structural impediments that Labor was unable to deal with. Those are the matters that this government is committed to dealing with.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister. I refer to your answer to the Leader of the Opposition a moment ago that job creation depended on the passage of your industrial relations legislation. I also refer to your statement to similar effect on Face to Face on Sunday night.
—Can you refer to the question, too?

—Yes. I am asking him whether he remembers. In the case of Mr Fischer, it is very important to check that he remembers things he might have said three days ago. Did you say that by far the best way to create jobs, to get unemployment down, would be for the government's IR bill to be passed? Do you agree that these statements are utterly inconsistent not only with what is in the budget papers and what the Treasury officials were saying last night but also with what your Treasurer himself was reported as saying in the Age last week; namely, that it was productivity improvement that was driving this legislation—

—And that unemployment `was not really why we do it'?

—Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: this is two days in a row that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has got up at question time and done a preamble of about 20 sentences before getting to a question. I ask you to draw that to his attention and get him to ask a simple question.
—Thank you very much. I do agree with the point of order and I would ask you to get to the question.

—Aren't your statements inconsistent with what your Treasurer is saying, that unemployment is `not really why we do it'—why we have this industrial relations legislation? As Acting Prime Minister, are you now going to bring the Treasurer to heel?
—No, no and no.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. The Prime Minister announced on 30 August that the Productivity Commission would undertake an inquiry into the private health insurance industry. Would the Treasurer please inform the House why the government is undertaking such an inquiry?
—Sheer frustration. Why didn't the question go to the minister for health? What's wrong with him?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition normally turns around and talks to his front bench when I answer a question, but he is surprisingly animated over this.
—Treasurer, resume your seat. We will wait until the Leader of the Opposition is finished. Then we will call the Treasurer again.
—Mr Acting Speaker—
—You have not got the call. I am just waiting for you—

—On a point of order: this is a question related to the organisation of the health rebate and the investigation of the private health insurance industry. Should that not be a question to the minister for health? If not, why not?

—On the point of order: it is a question about the Productivity Commission, for which I am responsible. Your point of order was about as comprehensible as your deputy's questions. And now he turns around. Turn back! Listen to this! He always turns around at this point. We used to do that when we were in opposition. We turned around when we knew the bucket was coming. We know all of these tricks. You learnt them from us.

ANSWER.PARA: You can turn around on this one because I am announcing that today we have released the terms of reference for the Productivity Commission inquiry into private health insurance. The terms of reference have been framed following close consultations between me, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health and Family Services. The inquiry will be undertaken by Executive Commissioner Gary Banks, Commissioner Helen Owens and Dr Brendan Kearney, who will be appointed as a part-time associate commissioner for the purpose of the inquiry. Dr Kearney comes with a considerable wealth of experience to assist with this inquiry. He has been the chief executive officer of the Royal Adelaide Hospital and director of the Institute of Medical and Veterinary Science for over 10 years. He has had a long and distinguished career.

The inquiry will cover the structure and conduct of the industry and seek to contribute to efficiency and competitiveness. The private health insurance industry is a significant part of Australia's health system and this inquiry will make an invaluable contribution, providing a comprehensive picture of the industry and the regulatory environment under which it operates. It will be conducted against the background of the government's commitment to retain Medicare, bulkbilling and community rating and to encourage individuals and families to take out private health insurance through financial incentives.

In order to avoid unnecessary bureaucratic duplication, I have requested the Productivity Commission undertake the legislation review for the Health Insurance Act 1973, part 3, and the National Health Act 1953, part 6 and schedule 1, as part of the inquiry, which had previously been scheduled for 1997-98.

We encourage all interested parties to make submissions—even the ACTU, which has put a ban and a boycott on the Productivity Commission of recent times, I noticed. They will be welcome to remove their ban and boycott and put any submissions that they might wish to do. The report will be presented to the government by February of next year, and the Productivity Commission will be releasing an issues paper shortly.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister and Minister for Trade. Is it not a fact that many major multi national companies have been encouraged to set up their regional headquarters in Australia as a result of government encouragement and promotion? Is he aware that the former government's regional headquarters program, which this government gutted in the budget, encouraged 92 new regional headquarters to be set up in Australia since 1993, attracting an estimated $2 billion in investment and at least 9,000 jobs? In the light of this, I ask him whether he endorses the Prime Minister's comments in Jakarta:

QUESTION.PARA: Neither do I see Australia as a bridge between Asia and the West as is sometimes suggested.

I ask the Acting Prime Minister and Minister for Trade whether he is similarly willing to dismiss, with a wave of the hand, a central role for Australia in the growing inter‐bloc trade between Asia and the West, a role that can clearly create and already has created thousands of jobs for Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his timely question. I express a regret that the poor old shadow minister for trade gets squeezed out by these big bullies down the centre, as does the shadow minister for tourism. There is one dead hole seat in this House and I know where it is: it is on that end of the front bench under the lee of the press gallery, out of sight and out of mind. Why won't they give you a go, Stephen?

ANSWER.PARA: I am very happy whenever ministers of the Australian coalition government go abroad. When the Prime Minister goes abroad he goes to represent Australia's interests, first and foremost, not Asia's interests in Europe, not Europe's interests in Asia, but Australia's interests. It is in that context that I support the Prime Minister's comments that Australia cannot be a bridge to Asia in a cultural or political sense.

But in relation to the economic linkages, business operations and trade and investment, it is absolute that we want to maximise the connection in every direction. We will do that as a consequence of a range of decisions we have already taken. I happily confirm the policy partly alluded to by the Leader of the Opposition but released under `Meeting the challenges', the Liberal and National Party trade strategies for the future, which said:

We will promote Australia to the European Union and to the United Kingdom, in particular, as a bridge to the Asia‐Pacific region and, therefore, as a solid base for EU trade and investment, separate from a cultural bridge. Especially, we intend to enhance Australia's attractiveness as a financial centre and as a base for the location of regional headquarters in the Asia‐Pacific.

So there is no difference between the thrust of your question and the policy of the previous government—but one, perhaps, and I will come back to that—and the policy of this government. Indeed, it was when the Minister for Finance was Premier of New South Wales that a great deal of progress was made with regard to the Cathay Pacific headquarters in Sydney, a very good example of that type of important economic development.

I would like to point out to members of the opposition that there is one area of practice in which we differ in respect of visits to Asia by Prime Ministers. You might remember that Prime Minister Keating was on Indonesian soil when he sought to rewrite the constitution and redesign our flag. Our Prime Minister will never, ever do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Can the Minister inform the House of any recent indicators of the success of former government business enterprises now operating in the private sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Members may have seen recent press reports about the results of Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. I remind honourable members Commonwealth Serum Laboratories was the first Labor government asset sale to proceed by way of public share offer. That occurred in May 1994 and the Labor government at the time received some $292 million for the sale of Commonwealth Serum Laboratories.

ANSWER.PARA: The company has recently announced its results. It showed an 18 per cent lift in profits to $24.5 million on sales of $290 million. Those sales were up some 13.5 per cent in the year to June. In the two years since the float the share price has more than doubled—from $2.30 at the time of issue to $6 today. This was the privatisation that the former Minister for Finance and now Leader of the Opposition had in mind when he spoke to the Press Club on 24 August 1994 on the merits of privatisation. Let me remind the House of some of the things that the Leader of the Opposition said at that time. He said:
The primary objective driving the privatisation program is to make Australia an efficient, internationally competitive economy.
Mr Acting Speaker, we agree. He said:

The focus of debate on efficiency measures such as privatisation and competition policy is often on job losses but it is more important to realise the efficiency gained from the pursuit of competition creates jobs.
We agree. He said:.
Privatisation fits in with the government's broader imperative to create jobs.
We agree. So does the commentator Stephen Bartholemeusz, who recently said in the Age when commenting on the CSL results:

CSL's experience would appear to be the clearest demonstration of the benefit of the privatisation effects of moving a government‐owned business operating in commercial markets into private ownership. In 1994 at the point of privatisation it had international revenue that represented 12 per cent of its revenue base. Today 27 per cent of its revenue comes from offshore activity. That kind of expansion was impossible for a publicly owned CSL, not just because of capital constraints but because the political risk reward equation was so biased against it.

Stephen Bartholomeusz went on to say that this is exactly the equation that Telstra faces. I believe that the Leader of the Opposition had Telstra in mind back in August 1994 when he addressed the press club and said:
The "net gain"—
of privatisation—

can take many forms: potentially better services and lower prices for consumers; stronger enterprises and greater competition for our economy; and in the broader sense, making government funds available for new policy.

That is exactly what the government wants to do. It wants to ensure that the most significant environmental program in this nation's history gets the $1 billion for the trust fund out of the partial sale of Telstra to proceed with those new policies—that is, new policy that is in the interests of Australia.

I am surprised because only this morning the Leader of the Opposition, commenting on a particular debate in the other chamber yesterday and a vote expressed by Senator Harradine, said, `The road to privatisation is a hard one for us to bite on.' It wasn't hard to bite on back in the National Press Club in August 1994 when he made it abundantly clear that it was in the interest of Australia to ensure that there were those businesses that governments should not be in, that they should be out there. Telstra was in the Leader of the Opposition's mind at that stage. Sadly, he now goes down to political expediency for narrow, short‐term, political gain. He has no credibility on the subject of privatisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker. It goes to relevance. The minister is constantly asserting that somewhere or other in this speech he can read my mind that there was a proposition for privatisation of Telstra. Perhaps he would like to read that portion of the speech, since he has asserted it now for five minutes, which allegedly calls for the privatisation of Telstra.
—There is no point of order. I assume that the Leader of the Opposition was not suggesting that the state of his mind was irrelevant.

—I am merely pointing out that the Leader of the Opposition has gone into a backflip on the subject of privatisation. He has no credibility on the subject. The Australian people will judge him and his party harshly on the basis of their hypocrisy on Telstra and on privatisation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

—I am asking you.
—My question is to the Acting Prime Minister. Given that you have referred that particular response and question to the minister, do you agree with him as it affects TPIs?

—I am proud of the fact, as one opposition frontbencher decided to attack me, that I served my country. I will not accept an attack on that from any grub on the front bench.

—I will withdraw that, if that offends. I just get a bit worked up when people make comments like that. Secondly, I stand by the answer given by my colleague the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who has detailed responsibility for this specific matter.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I draw the minister's attention to the large number of unemployed people, particularly long‐term unemployed people, in my electorate of Robertson and throughout Australia who cannot find jobs because of Labor's policy failures. What action is the government taking to get rid of this legacy from Labor and to help unemployed people obtain work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Robertson for his question. The fact that trend unemployment has been stalled now for some time at 8.6 per cent is one of the most tragic legacies of the Labor government. Today's figures, which show a rise in seasonally adjusted long-term unemployment by 13,000 and in trend unemployment by 3,000, are now revealing the full dimension of Labor's legacy.

ANSWER.PARA: The Labor Party claimed that it was going to help the long-term unemployed. The facts in the Working Nation evaluation statement are very, very different. The share of labour market assistance for the long-term unemployed actually fell during the Working Nation period. There was an eight per cent reduction in job referrals for the long-term unemployed under Working Nation. There was a three per cent fall in their share of jobstart placements. There was no change overall in their share of training program placements.

The Working Nation program was very good, however, at one thing; that is, redefining the long-term unemployed as short-term unemployed. Of course, the member for Hotham has said that he totally rejects that interpretation of Working Nation. He says that it did not have that effect. Once again, the facts are very different. I would like to quote the Working Nation evaluation statement about the impact of redefinition. The evaluation concluded:
This leaves the Job Compact open to charges of `recycling' clients from long-term to short-term unemployment, rather than substantively improving their labour market prospects.

These are not our words; they are the objective conclusion of an evaluation process established by the member for Hotham himself. If he was less busy evaluating his prospects for the deputy leadership, he would be able to face up to the truth. As the merry-go-round slows, we are now seeing in today's figures the full scale of the problem that you have left behind.

This government, by contrast with the Labor Party, takes its obligations to the long-term unemployed seriously and does not treat them just as pawns to advance the minister's career in the short term. We will be enlisting the resources of the private sector job placement agencies who will be contracted to make connections between long-term unemployed people and real jobs. We will be putting a major emphasis on incentives for job placement agencies to achieve a full employment outcome.

PARA.BREAK: Over the next four years this government will be spending $5.4 billion on assistance to unemployed people. It is true that we are not maintaining the massive wasteful expenditures that came out of the pockets of Australia's families during the locust years of Paul Keating—the locust years when he was piling up that $70 billion of deficits which you were too weak to prevent and which did not offer any effective assistance to unemployed people. It is now time for Labor and the Demo crats in the Senate to get on with passing the government's programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: in accordance with the standing orders that you drew to my attention last week, I would ask that you intervene to ensure that the minister addresses the Leader of the Opposition, or refers to his seat, correctly so that we have an even-handed, objective performance from the chair.

—I thank the honourable member for his point of order, and I will always endeavour to uphold that point of order, as with the others. But I do remind him of the time last week when he was speaking at the dispatch box and three times called the Prime Minister by an incorrect name, and on the fourth time I called your attention to that. So I will be even-handed and ask the minister to do the same.
—I have finished.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. It follows the answer which the minister gave recently concerning the $130 million the government intends to grab from elderly, frail and sick Australians seeking access to nursing homes. Will the average cost to people who require—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TUCKEY

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: I draw your attention to standing order 144, relating to question time. It says:

INTERJECT.PARA: The following general rules shall apply to questions:

I am sure that any study of today's Hansard would show that only one question, coming from a past expert, the previous Speaker, would have met that criteria. Every other question, including this question, has been debated and accompanied by a statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. I have received your point of order.
—Will the average cost to people who require access to nursing homes be $26,000?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me again advise the opposition of the details of the government's entry contribution policy. The entry contribution policy is not compulsory. It is an amount paid after negotiation between the service provider and the resident. Residents who are in a nursing home for less than six months or those who are financially disadvantaged will not be able to be charged an entry contribution fee.

ANSWER.PARA: My department estimates that only 45 per cent of all residents who are in a nursing home for longer than six months will pay an entry contribution fee.

TALK.START.PARA: —What will they pay?
—That entry contribution fee will be drawn down by $2,600 per annum for a maximum of five years. The total amount paid—regardless of what the entry contribution fee is—is $13,000 over the five years.

ANSWER.PARA: The government does not impose the entry contribution fee. The government does not set the level of the entry contribution fee. It does not receive any of the funds that are paid by way of entry contribution fees. My department estimates that the entry contribution will raise up to $130 million in the full year. That will comprise the draw down of $2,600 per annum plus a component for interest, which is retained by the provider.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, so what is the average?

—The balance of the entry contribution fee is returned to the resident when they leave the establishment or is returned to their estate. I hope that that will satisfy the questions asked constantly by the opposition on this matter.
—I have a supplementary question.
—I will hear the supplementary question, but I will not guarantee to permit it.
—Will the minister confirm the average is $26,000?
—It is the same question. You ought to name her.
—No, that is not a supplementary question.

—I address my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is the minister aware of young Australians' growing interest in honouring and remembering this country's wartime legacy? Has the government put in place any initiative to encourage and promote this interest?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Northern Territory for his interest, along with the interest of the member for Paterson. I advise the House that today I had the pleasure of participating in the inaugural schools wreath laying ceremony at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at our national War Memorial.
—Was it a Peter `Reith' laying ceremony?
—Order! The member for Banks! That is inappropriate.
—Demand a withdrawal.
—Order! The member for Melbourne!

—The school that participated today was the Metford Public School, and those students, I understand, are in the gallery today. They are from the member for Paterson's electorate. ANSWER.PARA: The interest from the next generation Australians, particularly from schools and students, is something that I and members on this side of the House are well aware of. Can the minister inform the House whether expressions of interest in the possible sale of business units of Australian National Rail are to be sought, as was reported in the media last week; are the reports of major losses resulting from the implementa tion of AN's corporate plan correct; and, if so, when was the plan approved and by whom?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Grey for his question. He has had a long interest in this issue of AN.
—See whether you can tell the truth, this time!

—I hear the member for Kingsford-Smith saying, `How about telling the truth?' I will answer the question put by the member for Grey and also, in the process, answer the claims made by the member for Kingsford-Smith in his personal explanation to the House last Thursday afternoon.

ANSWER.PARA: Today in question time, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) asserted that I had approved a business plan for Australian National that involved the loss of 950 jobs. The question asked by the honourable member for Grey affords me the opportunity to take up your challenge—a challenge I welcome.

I refer to a letter written by the former Minister for Transport, the member for Kingsford-Smith, to the Chairman of the Australian National Railways Commission, Mr Jack Smorgon, on 18 September 1995. That letter refers to the Australian National corporate plan. The second paragraph reads—and this is from Mr Brereton:
The plan provides a clear framework for the restructured organisation to follow for the next planning period and I approve the 1995‐96 financial target and the plan.
`I approve it'—`and the plan'. Indeed, in that plan—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not 950 redundancies.

—I hear the member for Kingsford-Smith saying that none of these details were in that plan. In that plan on page 35, it highlights the number of redundancies or job losses that would be taking place at AN. Indeed, I have to admit that I did somewhat misinform the House last week when I said that it was some 950 jobs that would be going under Labor's secret plan for AN. I was wrong. ANSWER.PARA: I understand that there has been close consultation between officials of AN and the Departments of Transport and Finance in the preparation of the plan. I consider the plan is comprehensive and thoroughly prepared. AN should be congratulated on this.

Indeed, if anybody had any doubts and they could not read the figures in the plan, AN provided very nice graphs to prove just how many jobs would be taken out as a conse quence of the corporate plan that was being approved by the then Labor government.

I asked in the House last week: did the then Minister for Transport and the then Prime Minister, when they visited AN's workshops at Islington, inform those workers of what they were proposing to do, what they had secretly signed off in this corporate plan? Of course they did not. Indeed, what we now know is that the Labor Party, when in government, had a plan not only to take away 972 jobs from AN but also, of course, as part of that plan, as we have seen reports of, that various aspects of AN would be advertised for sale.

So, indeed, I take up the challenge put by the member for Kingsford‐Smith in his personal explanation. I take up that challenge and prove the point in the House today that it was Labor's secret plan that the member for Kingsford‐Smith tried to deny last week which has placed AN in such a parlous circumstance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the member for Makin on her question. Her first name is obviously not Dorothy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The job security of workers at Australian National
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There are several thousand workers—mostly in South Australia in areas like Adelaide and Port Augusta and, to a lesser extent, in Tasmania—who are very fearful for their jobs and have been so for several months. Sadly, their fate is in the hands of a minister who appears not to care about their future, who wants to take the decisions about their future in secret and who wants to deny them the opportunity to participate in debate about the report which appears to be establishing that sad future.

SPEECH.PARA: I will run through the essence of what has occurred with respect to Australian National in the past few months. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), received the report on time on 19 June, as requested. He has been to cabinet at least twice on the issue. He has even established the partly backbench committee with people like the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) and the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin) on the committee. The committee does not appear to have done anything as yet. He has refused to release the report, in spite of the fact that workers in Australian National are understandably worried about their future and worried about their jobs, and he has refused to give any indication of its recommendations or its findings. Finally, after three months, when he is forced to release the report via the Senate by Labor in the Senate, all we get is the executive summary—and a doctored executive summary at that.

Because of the excuse of commercial in confidence, the minister says, `Sorry, we can't give you the full report. We can't give you the data on which the analysis is based. We can't give you the evidence that sustains the analysis of the financial situation of Australian National. All we can give you is the executive summary, but that itself has also got to be changed in order to protect commercial in confidence.' That excuse is probably half valid in one or two examples but, when you actually go through the report and the undoctored version—which we also happen to have obtained—you will see that there are several instances where commercial confidentiality has got nothing to do with the doctoring, and that politics has got everything to do with it.

For example, a statement in the original version saying `The recent decision to abolish the corporate office of Australian National' does not appear in the version tabled in the Senate. Equally, a recommendation that the Tasmanian government should be subsidised to take over AN operations in Tasmania, but only if it meets competition policy criteria in the competition policy agreement, is also deleted. We might well ask what is in the full report if such perversions have occurred with respect to even the executive summary?

Commercial in confidence is simply a fig leaf for the minister to try to hide the real debate, the real reasons and the real issues that hang over the heads of the workers in Australian National. But that slipping and sliding, that ducking and weaving, is nothing compared with the events that have occurred since the release of the report. First we had the minister say in the tabling statement that was tabled in the Senate by Senator Tambling, `Oh, we haven't made any decisions yet. Don't panic, don't worry, this report is a report to the government. It is not a report of the government. We haven't made any decisions. We are considering all options.' I will quote Senator Tambling's statement to make this very explicit. He said:

However, it is only one of several sources of information being considered, and it is not necessa rily indicative of the decisions the Government will take. The perception, which seems to be widely held, that the Report will be implemented, cannot be sustained at present. What elements of the report are to be implemented, if any, is yet to be decided.
No‐one should assume the Government will be implementing this report in making decisions about their future.

Pretty unequivocal and pretty explicit stuff: `Do not worry, people working at AN. Do not worry, families of workers at places like Port Augusta and Islington. Do not worry because we are not necessarily going to do any of these things.'

In his statements to the House in answer to a question on 11 September—last Wednesday—the minister said, `No, don't worry. We're not necessarily going to do any of these things. No decisions have yet been made.' And, predictably enough, all of this is the former government's fault. I will give a couple of quotes:
The previous Labor government and its ministers ignored all those warnings. What did they do about it? They just sat by and watched.

Remember that: they just sat by and watched. Then things got a bit interesting. The following day we came across a press release from Australian National and a draft advertisement that was apparently due to appear in the newspapers. To the best of our knowledge it has not yet appeared, but presumably it will.

That advertisement specified that Australian National was going to sell off four of its eight key businesses, including its workshops at Port Augusta and Islington, its infrastructure services division, and its wagon and loco maintenance and services divisions, but not—I emphasise not—any rail track or any of the rail corridor. There was a familiar ring about this press release and a familiar ring about the content of the advertisement. They set a few bells ringing. When we referred back to the content of the Brew report executive summary that we got the day before, it was a dead ringer. It was a remarkable coincidence—extraordinary. The advertisement and the content of the press release were all smack on—all dead on. Exactly the sorts of things that have been recommended by Mr Brew in his recommendations to the minister. An extraordinary coincidence.

BREAK.PARA: In question time that day, not surprisingly, the minister was asked by the member for Adelaide—no doubt at his instigation—`Why is it that these things are occurring if the government is making no decisions?' If the government has no preconceptions about what it is going to do with respect to the Australian National situation, why is it that, literally within hours of the Brew inquiry report being tabled in the Senate, a press release came out from Australian National containing almost all of the Brew package, all of the key components, all of the really nasty bits. It was there in black and white. It said, `Yes, we are seeking expressions of interest from the private sector about selling off all of these businesses', and, `Yes, that probably means lots of workers losing their jobs.' Why was this happening? The minister's response was, `Oh, but this is all Labor's fault'—the same Labor that was not doing anything. He said:

These reports about the possible sale of AN's assets and of major job losses at AN emanate from the fact that these sales and these job losses were planned in the business plan of the previous Labor government.

We have heard some more about all of that today. We were told that it was nothing to do with the minister, that there are no nasty decisions on his hands. He is not going to be slashing anybody's jobs. He is just an innocent bystander in this situation. He is just there watching; he is looking back more in sorrow than in anger saying, `Isn't it all a pity that this is happening to Australian National. But it is nothing to do with me; I am not making any decisions. Don't worry.'

There are two things that can be said about this. The first is the obvious point that the minister's line on 12 September totally contradicted his line on 11 September that Labor had done nothing. On the first day, he was telling us, `No, Labor ignored all these things, it did not do anything.' On the second day he was telling us `Jobs are being slashed by Labor.' The second and more fundamental point is that this statement was patently untrue. On Wednesday, 11 September he told us, `Labor had ignored all the warnings. Labor had sat by and watched. Labor was asleep at the wheel.' But on Thursday, 12 September, he told us that all the sell‐offs that were going to occur, that were put in train at the same time as the Brew report was handed down, were all planned by the previous Labor government in its business plan.

The previous Labor government would have to have been the most remarkable government in history. Not only did it tackle these problems when they came up, but it actually came up with a response that was so clairvoyant that it exactly matched the results of an inquiry that was set in train after it lost office. What an extraordinary performance! What an amazing performance! It is very nice of you to impute such clairvoyance to the previous government; it is not something that we are used to from your side. But it does test your credibility just a fraction. Which is it? Was Labor sitting and doing nothing? Or did it initiate these proposals that you are now trying to wash your hands of? Did it initiate the job losses that you now claim you have nothing to do with? Both cannot apply.

Unfortunately for the minister, the following day was Friday the 13th, which was a bit of an unlucky day for him. A letter came into the possession of the opposition which threw a bit of light on this. The real truth about what had been going on started to emerge. The person who instructed Australian National to do these things, the person who was making the decision to ensure that substantial numbers of workers—hundreds, possibly thousands of workers—would lose their jobs, the person who had initiated the decision to let loose four of AN's big employing businesses, was the minister himself.

The minister has been pretty good at quoting from letters today. I have got a letter too. It is even more interesting than the one that he quoted from. I am prepared to table this letter. Maybe he should respond in kind with the letter that he refers to. This letter of 15 August to Mr Smorgan, the chair of AN, says, amongst other things:
AN may also proceed to advertise its businesses for sale as you propose in your letter of 4 July.
In other words, he gave explicit approval for precisely what occurred. I seek leave to table that letter.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has played very fast and loose with the truth. He said that there were no decisions. `We have not got any preconceptions. We have not made up our mind.' Why has he chosen to hide his own involvement in these decisions and his own pre-emptive strike to implement the Brew recommendations and slash hundreds, possibly thousands, of jobs from Australian National in South Australia and Tasmania? I will tell you why he has done this. All the time his plan was to release the Brew report only at the time he announced his decisions. He has actually said that. He is not going to let the workers of Australian National even have a say about their future. He is not going to allow them the possibility of challenging the conclusions of the Brew report or the issues being put forward, or of going through the figures. The key elements of the new regime are: retention of the current 5.251 million tonne ceiling on export volumes, additional quantities of up to one million tonnes of woodchips to be sourced from sawmill residues and silvicultural thinnings from regrowth forests, and case by case approval for the export of woodchips sourced from the clearing of degraded private forests for the establishment of hardwood plantations. Obviously, there are similarities between the government's announced policy on woodchip exports and the regulations which operated previously. There was in fact some ill‐informed banter—which is probably the best way to put it—about this place that suggested these similarities meant that the government could not give legislative effect to its policy. This was always untrue. That has not stopped those who are opposed to the implementation of rational forest policy in this country from promoting all sorts of weird and wonderful distortions of reality. They have really become extremely skilled at making a great deal out of nothing.

Last week, the former regulations were deemed to have been disallowed in accordance with section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, and that brings me to the purpose of the motion now before the House. Section 49 of the Acts Interpretation Act provides that any regulation being the same in substance as the regulation so disallowed, or deemed to have been disallowed, has no effect if made within six months of disallowance, but it also identifies two circumstances where this provision does not apply.

The circumstances relevant to the motion now before the House states that a regulation the same in substance may be made where the house of parliament in which a regulation was deemed to have been disallowed resolves to approve the making of such a regulation. Passage of this motion is essential if the government is to give full legislative effect to its policy. However, like the regulations which will be made in the near future, it is not essential for the government to implement its policy.

The regulations in existence today, the old unprocessed wood regulations which predated Labor's ill-conceived arrangements, are adequate to implement the government's transitional woodchip licensing system, but it is the government's very strong preference to now secure the new arrangements in regulations. There are obvious benefits in doing so, not the least of which is keeping the pressure on the states to stay the course with implementing regional forest agreements. This will be achieved by ensuring that woodchip exports cease from areas not covered by regional forest agreements by the year 2000.

Having said this, I want to make it absolutely plain that I am completely confident that the cooperative federalism—in which we have engaged since coming to government, in contrast to the very heavy-handed approach of the previous government—will ensure that the year 2000 sanction will not be required. It will not have to be used. It will not have to be invoked.

The public has not been misled into believing that all woodchip exports from our forests will cease after 2000. Woodchips will continue to be exported after regional forest agreements as part of an integrated, sustainable and internationally competitive native forest logging industry—and I will return to this in a moment. I should just note, lest anybody wanted to make a political point out of that, that the previous government's position, despite their attempts to hide officegate or whatever on this matter, was in fact precisely the same. So let us not have any fudging or attempts to mislead in that regard.

As I have said, I will return to this shortly, but I want firstly to talk about the other key aim of the national forest policy statement—that is, the creation of a comprehensive, adequate and representative forest reserve system. There are those who would have it that our forests are not well protected. Essentially, this is simply not the case. A little over a fifth of our forests enjoy some form of protection, whether they be national parks, state conservation reserves or other protected areas. This is substantially more than the international benchmark of 10 per cent of existing forests set by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature. We have already the basis for the CAR reserve system envisaged under the national forest policy statement, an outcome to which this government is absolutely committed.

The government remains committed to seeking 15 per cent of the distribution of each forest type that existed prior to European settlement as a target, but it must be understood clearly that this target will be extremely difficult or impossible to achieve in some areas, most particularly in northern New South Wales and south-east Queensland. In these areas, the government will proceed carefully, taking full and proper account of the social and economic consequences that would flow from locking away large tracts of forest. We will not decimate—I repeat, we will not decimate—rural communities.

It is important to set down on the public record a few facts about the forest industries. In particular, it needs to be understood that the timber industry is sawlog driven. Forest coupes are felled to supply timber for milling. Woodchips are produced from the leftovers—from the logs that failed to make milling grade, from sawmill and timber harvesting residue and from silviculture thinnings in regrowth forests.

The reality is that a large volume of the timber that is felled ends up as woodchips— or, rather, could end up as woodchips if the industry were not so heavily constrained by current regulation. This integrated harvesting, the taking of both sawlogs and pulpwood, makes sense. It underpins the profitability of our native forest based industry. It maximises the use of the available resource and adds significantly to the nation's export income.

Integrated harvesting is more than merely good economics; it represents good environmental practice as well in many of the eucalypt forests of Australia where the forest canopy needs to be opened up in order to get the forest to regenerate. Prior to European settlement, fire was the regenerator; in the managed forests of today, where fire is feared, modified clear-fell harvesting fulfils this role.

In those forests where intensive logging is inappropriate, state forest managers permit selective logging only. The message here is that the harvesting method is tailored to the forest type. As the member for Page (Mr Causley), who is here today, would well know, those forestry management techniques are highly sophisticated, very carefully thought through and increasingly are reflective of a culture of immense expertise. That needs to be clearly understood.

Under the previous export arrangements the timber industry, regulated by the states through strict planning procedures and codes of environmental practice, was not allowed to utilise much of the wood it harvested. That is the simple reality that was left behind by the absurdity of the previous government's attempts to satisfy the Greens. They failed in that, so they got it wrong from an industry perspective, wrong from a conservation perspective—and wrong certainly from the point of view of regional Australia, as is quite adequately reflected by the make‐up of the opposition today: wrong with a capital `W' in regional Australia.

The results of their politicisation and cynicism in this whole thing was that a large amount of wood was either burned or left to rot on the forest floor—which, in itself, heightens future fire risk and seriously retards post-harvest regeneration. TALK.START.PARA: —What we said is that we wouldn't destroy small country towns, and that's what you have done.

—The minister is simultaneously saying, `There will not be a problem in getting adequate reserves.' He can't have it both ways. He can't have the argument both that there is enough and that there is not enough.

BREAK.PARA: If you look at the changes, in my view, they spell disaster for a lot of our native forests; I agree that that is not so for all of them. TALK.START.PARA: —We said we wouldn't destroy small country towns and that's what you would have us do. You would pack them up and send them all off. Where to? The long‐term unemployment queue, which you believe is Valhalla. You have no idea.

BREAK.PARA: But, in addition to the change in woodchip ceilings, there is a very significant change, too, in the approval for what could amount to unlimited logging on privately owned land. I, for one, will be fascinated to see how he manages to define a degraded forest, in light of what we understand to be the national forest policy where, in some cases, the only forest that is representative of its type may well have suffered some form of degradation over years of logging and interference from other sources.

It is not only bad from the point of view of forest policy, it is also bad from the point of view of general environment policy. I am sure that, if the minister sits back from that from time to time, he will realise that that, and the removal of penalties to the states not making sufficient progress towards a comprehensive system of forest reserves, will completely derail the national forest policy. Do we always have to come from behind in the eyes of this government? If you look at their attitude to greenhouse and other issues, why is it that they think that Australia should be second or third or last in the line in this area? Because we are a relatively new nation from the point of view of European settlement, should we go the way of Europe and North America? Should we destroy all our forests? Should we go the way of developing nations in South‐East Asia who, without adequate controls, are ripping into theirs as well?

This was precautionary and decent. The 15 per cent level was one that was settled on after a lot of discussion as being reasonable and achievable and without significant dislocation to the forest industry. I think that is a fair conclusion from a whole lot of independent observers, not just on the conservation side. The worst impact here will be on high conservation value native forests. As I say, I think it is worse than the green light to record levels of woodchip exports. There is no guarantee at all now. We have none from the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), who is always taking second place to the Minister for Resources and Energy—

TALK.START.PARA: —Primary Industries.
—Sorry, I have given him a new title—Agriculture.
—Two wrong.

—Primary Industries—they change all the time. The Minister for the Environment is always taking second place to you. I commend you for that amount of personal power, but it is bad for the environment that Senator Hill is always trailing along behind you saying, `Yes, Minister, no, Minister', when it comes to the protection of our natural resources. We have no guarantees from this minister and no guarantees from the Minister for the Environment that the goal of establishing a truly comprehensive adequate and representative reserve system can be achieved, because the criteria are all being diluted. In my own state of Western Australia, the government there and CALM have the view that we have only got two forest types—karri and jarrah. They overlook all the regional and other varieties that it is clearly very important to preserve. With a state regime like that how can we guarantee, even with a 15 per cent criterion, that we are going to get decent preservation?

BREAK.PARA: In addition to scrapping the 15 per cent benchmark, the coalition has abandoned the previous government's sliding scale to protect 60 to 100 per cent of old growth forests depending on the percentage remaining within each forest type. We have already heard the minister hint at the fact that it is going to be too difficult to achieve some of these criteria in some places. The end effect of that is that rare and biologically diverse species remaining in our old growth forests will be bulldozed without a whimper from the federal government.

That is the consequence of the combination of policy changes we have seen from this government: a change to the ceilings; forestry on private land leading to an increase in woodchip exports; and a reduction, a dilution, of the criteria necessary to achieve decent forest protection in this society. The green movement is now awake up to you. The wider community will gradually realise that what you told them during the election campaign was the opposite, in fact, of what you intended to do and what you are now doing in government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously we have inherited a budgetary circumstance that is grossly unsatisfactory and which is really putting at risk Australia's capacity to perform to its maximum ability; its capacity to deliver not simply high standards of living and high take‐home pay levels but also job opportunities—particularly for young Australians—and we have got to do something about it. That is the reality that we face. I find it almost unbelievable. I have to say that I am still stunned. When we had a close look at the budgetary circumstances that confronted us, it was revealed that not only were we facing a deterioration in terms of that big black hole of about $8 billion‐odd dollars, but also that over the past five years the previous regime—which prided itself on being responsible economic managers and which publicly wanted the Australian community to swallow the line that they were responsible economic managers—had, once you stripped away the bells and whistles and the asset sales and so forth, racked up a total of $69,000 million in deficits. That is a truly horrifying amount.

SPEECH.PARA: The increase in Australia's position in terms of drawings on private sector savings and what have you is utterly unsustainable. It really puts at risk our capacity to forge ahead and to offer everybody maximum opportunities for economic self‐determination. It is vitally important that that issue be tackled, and we have sought to tackle it.

In terms of my portfolio area, I want to make it quite plain that there is nothing more important for primary industry than to get pressure of interest rates off. If you sit down and do the maths to establish just what an inhibitor high interest rates are to the farm sector, particularly when those interest rates are higher than those of our competitors abroad, you really do come to some startling conclusions. The figures are quite amazing.

On a typical small business loan taken out by Australian farmers to be repaid over a number of years, the extra amount of money Australian farmers would have to pay over and above what they would pay if they were on Japanese, American or even British interest rates is truly horrifying. It can make the difference between farms surviving tough times and farms going under. We have far too many of them going under.

The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) is sitting just behind me and he knows only too well what effect high interest rates have had in difficult circumstances out there. We had to get the pressure off them. I have been very relieved to note that farmers and rural leaders right across the nation have given the coalition the thumbs up for the approach we have taken in the budget repair task.

I have to say that it was not easy. It is never easy. No‐one—we ought to make this quite plain—enjoys having to withdraw financial support or contributions from anyone in the community. We in this place would all like to be generous and offer great largesse in every instance. That is almost the nature of the breed, yet the reality is that we had to make many decisions of a difficult nature in order to rein in the very alarming situation that we confronted.

As a member of the Expenditure Review Committee—one of the six who had that rather unpleasant task, and it was an unpleasant task—I do record my gratitude for the way in which rural Australia has accepted the fairness and equity, in every sense of those words, when it comes to considering the nation's future and the desirability of what we have proposed. Mr Deputy Speaker Vaile, I believe you would have discovered that in your electorate, particularly amongst the rural people with whom I am most concerned tonight.

What we really have is a strategy which will reduce the deficit by some $7.2 billion over the next two years, and we will move to a modest surplus over three years. Ironically, it meets the very test that the shadow Treasurer set for us and said that we ought to be meeting when he was trying to paste us on television. It represents a two per cent structural adjustment, if you like, as it seeks to bring revenue into line with outlays during the period of fiscal repair—the three years over which the budget surplus will be achieved.

It is enormously reassuring to note that the confidence engendered from this broad approach to economic management has seen a reduction in interest rates. It is very important to recognise and acknowledge that, in the context of a lot of sometimes quite ill-informed banter about the importance of regional Australia and what we are doing to them, getting these fundamentals right for rural economies is the greatest contribution a government can make. It is the No. 1 thing.

That half a per cent cut in interest rates is worth around $90 million minimum to the farm sector, particularly given that all banks have passed it on. That is a very substantial amount of money freed up not only in offering relief to farmers with big debts but also in enabling those who do not face such difficult circumstances to have the increased opportunity to do things like start reinvesting.

That leads me to a very important aspect of our budgetary approach, which is to acknowledge the very real need to boost domestic savings. One of the issues frequently raised with me as I move around the bush is the very high level of foreign investment in much of Australia's rural infrastructure, particularly in the processing sector. The government welcomes foreign investment. We recognise that it has always been the case in Australia that a considerable degree of foreign investment has been in our interest, whether it has been to build our railways and bridges in the old days or to build modern processing plants today to help participate in modernising and developing our economy. However, it needs to be noted that it is an extraordinarily important principle that Australia's saving levels need to be boosted so that we encourage investment by Australians in our industries.

I do record my real concern that there is a reluctance on the part of the Australian community to invest in, for example, the food processing sector. Our abattoirs through to the sophisticated food processing industries that are very much the key to our trading performance in Asia in the future all have seen, in my view, starvation of funding from Australians.

I think it is important that we recognise the need to withdraw the hand of government in terms of its heavy impost on people's savings, people's pockets, in recent years; to leave more money, if you like, in private circulation to boost the size of the domestic pool of savings, which will obviously free up money for investment outside of government activities. It is vitally important that we get the private sector going again.

PARA.BREAK: The key outcome for primary industry is that this budget keeps costs down. It main tains an appropriate support base whilst making a real contribution to expanding the options in terms of market access and market facilitation in the future. There are other aspects of the budget that are obviously of great interest and importance to the rural community.

SPEECH.PARA: The retention of the diesel fuel rebate in very difficult economic circumstances is a recognition of the importance of the scheme to keeping costs down, not just for domestic production, not just for our farming and mining sectors and the jobs that they provide locally in terms of those activities on the ground, but also because they are overwhelmingly export industries.

No sensibly managed economy features high levels of indirect taxation on exports. Indeed, I think in that regard the point needs to be made again that there appear to be some who would still paint the diesel fuel rebate scheme as a subsidy. I will continue to argue, until I am blue in the face, that it is no such thing. It is a mechanism for avoiding taxation on very significant input costs for many rural people—many farmers and many miners who are, of course, major contributors to Australia's export performance. In fact, the activities covered by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy contribute nothing less than 80 per cent to Australia's merchandise exports. To a huge slab of that activity, fuel is a very important input indeed.

In terms of other costs that are kept down in the budget, there is a $12 million contribution continuing to AQIS meat inspection, to the red meat program. The previous government failed, year in and year out, to deliver effective and meaningful reform. Despite the fact that industry currently pays very considerably too much for the services delivered, there is still a requirement for an ongoing subsidy. We will continue to provide that, although our objective is to wind it back in the near future as we move to a more efficient regime that costs less as we seek to restructure and rationalise in the meat program.

In terms of the support base that is provided by the government for agriculture, we have been quite active in the exceptional circumstances arrangements for drought. We have found another $90 million, a very substantial amount of money, to continue assistance mainly in eastern Australia, in a circumstance where much of the rural sector has seen some of its toughest seasons ever following on times of very low commodity prices and the aforementioned disastrously high interest rates.

At the same time, rural adjustment funding is up from $114 million in 1995-96 to around $124 million in 1996-97. That is a clear recognition of the government's commitment to assisting farmers to not only survive the very difficult current circumstances but also find their way forward on to a more productive, sustainable and viable future after the pounding they have taken in recent years.

I have just announced a major review of the rural assistance scheme and I have said a few things about possible future directions. I do not intend to comment from now on because I do not want to pre-empt the work that review team will undertake. Suffice it to say that, as minister for primary industry and as part of a government which shares my views in this regard, I am determined to do everything I can to help as many of our farm families as possible survive this downturn and return as quickly as possible to a genuinely attractive economic and lifestyle basis in the future. It is of critical importance to not just those directly involved but also the nation that we achieve that objective.

We have found another $14.6 million to strengthen the northern Australia quarantine service. That is a very important part of what the government recognises is a community responsibility—to secure our barriers against incursions of foreign pests and diseases to the greatest extent possible.

This is a vexed issue for Australia in the 1990s. We are a trading nation. The volume and the diversity of trade in and out of the country is exploding. The number of people who come into the country—Australians returning from abroad and visitors to our country as tourists—is exploding every year. Increasingly, the question of quarantine is a difficult one. The Nairn review is about to make a full report on our quarantine arrangements and the government will respond to that in due time. In the meantime, we have moved to very significantly upgrade our barrier protection in northern Australia, particularly in light of the sensitivity surrounding the papaya fruit fly incursion of last year.

There is a point I want to make here in relation to supermarket to Asia, which represents the government's very deep commitment to expanding our trade opportunities in Asia. During this decade it is estimated that the increase in consumer spending on food and fibre in Australia will be of the order of $6 billion. In other words, our domestic markets from our agricultural products will increase by about $6 billion. During the same period in Asia, they will increase by about $US160 billion—an astonishing figure.

As we learnt in this place yesterday, Australia has not been achieving its potential in that regard. The policies of the previous government—they failed to register the great key to any country's export performance as being tied to its being competitive at home—meant that, although those markets in Asia are expanding, we have been losing market share. Our supermarket to Asia strategy is a very carefully designed and constructed strategy which will see business and government pulling together and cooperating to identify the obstacles and bottlenecks, wherever they are inhibiting our trade performance in Asia.

As part of that, I want to touch on this quarantine arrangement because we have provided $2 million for market access expertise, which will be provided through AQIS. It is the positive side that we really have to look to in terms of this very vexed issue of imports. I do want to say—I say with real feeling—that I understand why Australians feel concerned about what appear to be increasing volumes of imported foodstuffs and what have you.

I can understand when people look at the grocery shelves and see imported product that they sometimes feel concerned. With such issues as imported salmon and so forth—the subject of much interest in recent times—I can understand and appreciate why people would initially have real concern about it. Under the previous government, Australia embarked upon a course of trade liberalisation and this government, in opposition, supported that approach—we continue to support it. What we have to recognise is that we have to get on the positive side of this and that there are tremendous opportunities opening up to us. The Minister for Trade, the Hon. Tim Fischer, is present in the gallery. He has a great long list of opportunities that have opened, or will shortly open, up to us, particularly in Asia, because of the emergence and the now following through of the new trade opportunities under the World Trade Organisation rules.

I say to potential exporters that we now have the capacity for you, through supermarket to Asia and through the export market facilitation scheme—the expertise thing—to be assisted as you seek access to new markets. That access has vastly improved and the expertise and technical backup are there. We need to look to the opportunities, remembering always that as a nation that exports five times as much agricultural product as we import the only thing we have to fear is a lack of competitiveness. The defence for Australia against imports is to be truly competitive; the opportunities are to do it better than anybody else, and the market opportunities in Asia are absolutely limitless. It is a permanent slight against the previous government that we ever got to a situation—I see the member for Dawson (Mrs De‐Anne Kelly) here—where American beef came into this country.

Here we are, the world's major exporter of beef. It is not necessary for us to apply quotas or tariffs. We cannot anyway when we are exporting all of our product over there. But it should never have been allowed to arise, simply because we ought to be far more competitive—and we can be and we should be.

We have invested in some very significant areas. Dollar for dollar, rural research remains because there is an enormous community which will benefit from those projects. I think it is one of the best models in existence in the whole of the Western world today. We have invested heavily in conservation—$58.4 million for 1,100 continuing and new landcare projects; more focus on catchment and regional action, enhanced planning skills of land‐holders, enhanced farm skills; $7.9 million for the national property management campaign; $98 million for the forest industry structural adjustment package; $32 million to the wood and paper industry strategy; and $48.6 million to regional forest agreements.

We have just heard a lot of nonsense from a couple of people on the other side who really cannot agree on very much about our forest policy. But there is the commitment that they said we lacked, the regional forest agreement—48 million reasons, in dollars.

TALK.START.PARA: —Delivered.

—Our commitment is delivered, to make sure that we engage in the highest quality, the most integrated approach, to assessing regional forest agreements that is possible. There is an extra $4.5 million to the Murray‐Darling Basin system and a lot more to come. When sense prevails and the Telstra bill is unlocked in the Senate, we will have sound policy environmentally, communications‐wise and in terms of public debt interest or PDI. We desperately need that in the interests of the nation, and I appeal to those who are contemplating their actions in this regard to allow it to go ahead, because it is a critical initiative for this country in every way. It is a genuine win‐win and, like the budget, it enjoys the very strong support of this nation's farm leaders. I appeal again to those who have doubts in this regard to listen to the nation's farm leaders. (Time expired)
