For instance, Karen Shaw, a working single parent in my electorate, has a three‐year‐old child in long day care. This woman wants to be a very productive member of our society. She has gone back to university and studied hard. She has a double masters degree and wants to contribute to the work force but the cost of child care will make that marginal for her. I think that is ridiculous. She wants to get out there into the work force and have a productive career, but these increased costs mean that that becomes a harder choice for her. That might be what the Prime Minister wants. Maybe he wants to tax people back into the homes; I don't know. Maybe this is a secret agenda. It could be. John Howard would like to think that we should go back to the 1950s, and maybe this is the way he sees that he can do that.

BREAK.PARA: I have a number of child‐care centres in my electorate. One is run by the Hurstville Council. It is not a Labor controlled council. The mayor is a member of the Liberal Party, as are a number of the aldermen. They are terribly concerned about these changes. They have a centre that caters for 40 children. They have 263 children on the waiting list. With this program they will not be able to expand this centre. It means that people in the Hurstville municipality will have to wait even longer.

I have been to rallies organised by the St George Advocates for Children. It is not some Labor Party front; it is run by Marie Ficarra, a Liberal Party member in the New South Wales parliament and the Liberal mayor of Hurstville. They are trenchant in their criticism of what this government has done for child-care facilities in the Hurstville municipality, which covers Ms Ficarra's state electorate and my federal electorate.

I have been to a meeting at Earlwood which was run not by a lot of Labor people; it was run by women. With two days' notice over 300 people attended to complain about this. These are not people who are traditional Labor voters. These are just worried women who see that what this government is doing is putting at risk the chance they have to contribute in the community in the way that they would want. What does the Howard government think about that? Nothing. These people probably have to suffer because they live in an electorate that has a Labor Party member as their local member.

These are sensible people. They do not want to hurt anyone. They do not want to harm anyone. At a meeting they went to it was suggested that they might demonstrate outside Mr Howard's expensive Sydney residence that we the taxpayers own. But they said, `No, the Prime Minister's wife is not well; we shouldn't go and do that.' They want to be decent people. But they are not being treated decently by this government at all. We have seen the same attacks on ordinary Australians in the health area. The mentality of this government seems to be, `If you can hurt them, hurt them and hurt them hard.'

The Commonwealth dental program was abolished in my electorate. Seventy per cent of the people who use the Canterbury dental clinic are pensioners. I happen to think that was one of the great innovations of the previous Labor government because it gave people a chance to go to the dentist to have their teeth fixed rather than having them pulled out. Unfortunately, one of the terrible things that used to happen to old people in Australia was that if they could not afford to go to the dentist, they went once and had their teeth pulled out. We put in a system where people could get proper dental care at minimal cost. I think that was a very good thing. That is something that we should have done to help the elderly in Australia.

But what does the Howard government do? They say, `If you cannot afford to go to one of the dentists that we go to, that is just bad luck for you. Take your teeth out.' They think that is how you help the elderly. Last year the Canterbury dental clinic gave out over 2,000 vouchers for emergency dental care to people who normally would not be able to go to the dentist.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not any more.

—As the shadow minister has indicated, not any more. On 21 August that scheme closed down. If you want to go to a dental hospital in the city now, you can take a long bus ride and wait three years for care. It is pretty rich if you have a toothache, that is all I can say.

BREAK.PARA: Henry Wicks from Campsie, in my electorate, is an 82‐year‐old man who has had all his teeth all his life and is proud of it. My father is like that. He is 83 and still has his teeth, and he thinks that is pretty good. It is pretty good; it is an achievement. But these people now cannot afford dental care. Because they cannot afford it, they will not be able to go into the dental program that the Commonwealth government was subsidising, and they will be in real strife.

I would like to know what the government has to say to those people. They will have to find $168 a year to buy themselves basic dental cover. If you are a pensioner, finding $168 a year is not an easy thing to do. But then again, ministers who are earning $150,000 a year probably do not think of that.

I asked the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) in question time a few weeks ago how he could justify this unconscionable attack on pensioners in my electorate. How do I tell people like Henry Wicks that they had better not go and get another Costello cavity because if they do they will have to find the money to pay for a dentist themselves? You and I know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that pensioners do not have that sort of money. That sort of attack on older Australians is just not fair. The government says that they are spreading the pain; they are certainly spreading the pain to people who can less afford this care.

We have seen the same sort of attack on older people through the nursing home entry fee. For the last few weeks we have seen in this House the Minister for Family Services obfuscating every day on the question whether you will have to pay a charge. Today she said that the government will not levy a charge and that it will be up to people who own these nursing homes to say whether there will be a charge.

The Prime Minister revealed the truth. In adding to the answer from this incompetent and inept minister a few weeks ago, the Prime Minister let the cat out of the bag. He said that if you have not owned a home in the last two years you will not be required to make a contribution. The other side of that coin is that if you have owned a home you will be required to make a contribution. What is the contribution? It is at least $26,000 a year. Even the minister, in trying to slip‐slide round this answer today, said that she did not know, that she could not quite tell us that no-one will make you pay, but that you will have to come up with at least $13,000.

We know that if you divide the amount that the government says that they are going to raise from this nursing home program by the number of nursing home beds there are in Australia, you arrive at the figure. There is a bit of simple arithmetic involved here, and even the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser), who is at the table, could do it. He should have been the Minister for Finance, but they gave him some other crumb‐bum job looking after Customs. If we asked him, even he would be able to tell us that if you divided one by the other you would get $26,000. You need $26,000 to get into a nursing home. That is what this government says to older people.

In my electorate there are 13 nursing homes, with 923 clients, four hostels and three home based care organisations. There are 1,124 clients in my electorate who will be hit by this charge. What do I say to those people? They do not have any other assets except the houses they live in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell them—

—Sell it! The silvertailed doctor from Bradfield says, `Tell them to sell.' Terrific. This is the sort of compassion that we get from the government. That is the truth of it all. These people will have to sell. If you do not have the $26,000 and the only asset you have in your life is your house, then you will have to sell.

BREAK.PARA: The Minister for Family Services has just come into the House. She would not answer the question today. Maybe before we finish tonight she might tell us the answer. Minister, do they have to pay the $26,000? She is pretty silent on this, isn't she? The truth is that they have to pay. The member for Forrest, who is sitting next to you, will do the sum for you, Minister. He will tell you that when you divide one by the other it comes out as $26,000, and that is what it will cost to get into a nursing home. If people do not own any other asset except their house, they will have to sell it.

Jean Young is a woman in my electorate who lives in Earlwood. If the minister says that I am telling a fib, she can ring Jean Young tomorrow and tell her not to worry. I would like to be able to say to Jean Young that she should not worry. She contacted me in despair about the nursing home entrance fees. Mrs Young is 86 and her husband is 84. They have no family to look after them, and her husband will soon have to go into a nursing home as he is having difficulties caring for himself and walking. She asked me what will happen if her husband goes into a nursing home. She said, `God forbid! I don't want to go into a nursing home, and I do not want to sell my house. What will happen to me? How will I be able to afford my husband's nursing home program?'

TALK.START.PARA: —You should tell her the truth.

—Well, Minister, tell me the truth. Does she have to pay? Tell the truth, Minister. It is a simple yes or no answer. The truth is that you know she has to pay. You are the one who decided the scheme and sillily let it go through without keeping a good eye on it. These people are going to have to pay $26,000, and if the only asset you have is your own home, you are going to have to sell it.

BREAK.PARA: That is where their memories are. People who own their own homes in electorates like mine—in Earlwood, Kingsgrove, Campsie and places like that—have been living in them for 50 and 60 years. These are not just fly‐by‐nighters; these are people who went through the Depression, went to the war and defended this country. Now they are being told in their 80s that if they get sick and have to go into a nursing home they have to cough up $26,000 and that if the only asset they have is their house—sell it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were charging them in hostels. It was your policy.

—Tell us it is not true, Minister. Tell us that they will not have to sell their house. Yes, she is pretty quiet on that, isn't she? You were pretty good at interjecting before, but when you have to answer the question, `Do they have to sell their house, do they have to find the $26,000?' you are pretty quiet.

BREAK.PARA: Maybe they will get it out of fresh air. They could get lucky, Minister. You are right—they might win the lottery. That is the only other way that they will find this money. In the House today the Deputy Prime Minister agreed that they are even going to make TPIs pay the $26,000. They are people who went to the war and became damaged for the rest of their lives. So what do we say to them?

Last year we had the Australia Remembers program. We all went to those functions. We all said to the old diggers, `What a great job you've done for Australia.' I was born the year the war ended. I feel a great debt to those people because they kept my country as a country for me to grow up in. What do we say to them in 1996 when they are in their 80s? They are TPIs. They are people who get a special pension from the government because they were injured in the war. We say to them, `Bad luck, Sport. You went through the Depression. You fought for your country. You are a TPI. You are now suffering and you've got to go into a nursing home, so cough up $26,000.' But they say, `All I've got, Leo, is my house.' `Sell it' is the government's answer to this statement. If there is an issue that points to the absolute callousness of this budget, it is that issue.

The government has also made cuts in lots of other areas. They have gone and said to people who receive services through the home and community care program—a program that I am proud to say I had a lot to do with in setting it up under the Labor government in the early 1980s—`You're going to have to pay an extra $6.30 a week to receive those services.' I suppose they will say, `The economics aren't too bad now. If I've got to find $26,000 to get in a nursing home, I can sell my house, but maybe I've got to find that $6.30 from somewhere because I can't afford the other option.'

This budget is a disgrace. It attacks ordinary Australians. It attacks the most vulnerable. It is the most vicious budget we have seen in this country in 20 years. Malcolm Fraser was a gentleman and a scholar compared to the people running this government. Malcolm Fraser at least had that patrician view that you should not belt the needy. All this government wants to do is belt the needy. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be a very enjoyable task this afternoon to debate some of the points that were raised by the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), but I do have an agenda in terms of Appropriation Bill (No. 1). I would like to remind the honourable member for Watson while he is still in the chamber, before he scurries out, what the Labor Party left behind. They gave us a foreign debt of $180 billion. Labor may have gone, but the debt is still here. We pay for it through higher taxes and higher interest rates and our children will still be paying for it unless we do something about it now.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year, Labor spent $10 billion of taxpayers' money as interest on government debt both here and overseas. Without a plan to meet our debts, that interest bill will get bigger and bigger. Paul Keating said that his budget brought home the bacon. This budget brings home the truth about 13 years of Labor excesses—13 years of foreign debt, not local jobs, and standing up for special interests, not for families and not for small business. The Labor Party spent money they did not have and they kept on spending, leaving us with a budget deficit of $8 billion. I could debate the other points he raised in terms of family services and health, but I am quite sure that the relevant ministers, in responding to the debate on the appropriation bills, will cover the points raised by the honourable member.

I rise in support of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1996, introduced by the Treasurer (Mr Costello). First of all, I would like to congratulate the Treasurer. The coalition government's first budget is particularly good, especially after the terrible financial mess the coalition inherited after 2 March.

The budget has excellent news for middle Australia as it has a solid platform from which Australians can work towards a better Australia. It is quite an equitable budget for all Australians, in particular for territorians. It is a good budget for rural Australia. It is a good budget for regional Australia. This responsible budget has been long overdue and will set Australia's economy back on course as it provides a solid base for economic growth.

Under Labor, Australia experienced Keating's recession—the one which Australia had to have. Despite 13 years, or 20 quarters, we still have not fully recovered from the recession we had to have. It was the one that drove Australia into the worst economic downturn faced in 60 years, the one which saw unemployment peak to the worst figures seen in this country since the Great Depression of the 1930s.

BREAK.PARA: Unemployment peaked at 11.2 per cent in December 1992 under Labor. Nearly one million Australians were out of work under Labor. Youth unemployment rose to a national average of 26 per cent under Labor. Some one million Australians lived in poverty with 600,000 of those being children, 14 years and younger, and this was confirmed by the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling in their May 1995 figures.

Today, the Australian community is left with a $10.3 billion black hole. Because of this deficit, we all have to tighten our purse strings. If it were not for the Beazley bankcard bill, which put Australia deeper and deeper into debt over 13 long years, we would not be facing such a difficult task.

The Australian community has been left with this terrible legacy by the former Labor government. It has had to be addressed. The Treasurer and the government have addressed it. To its credit, the coalition government has not tackled the problem in the usual cop-out manner adopted by our predecessors of simply raising taxes. At the 1993 federal election, the Keating government promised not to raise or introduce new taxes. To quote John Dawkins, the then Treasurer: `There will be reductions in expenditure and there will be no increase in taxes.' We all know what happened when they were re-elected.

In the appropriation bills a rather different approach has been taken by the coalition government. The government has trimmed the expenditure of government agencies and departments. This has been done without a doubt in a responsible and equitable manner. I remind all honourable members that this approach was foreshadowed during the election campaign.

Overall, the Northern Territory did not fare too badly. For example, we were the only state or territory to receive a special revenue assistance grant in this budget. Other areas in which the Northern Territory benefited relate to the commitment to defence in the Northern Territory, which has been not only maintained but also increased. In brief, the Northern Territory has also won in areas such as national landcare program grants, and the Northern Development Council is to be re- established and funded. Also, the Darwin based Australian Broadcasting Corporation's Australian Television received a boost to its funding of $6.4 million.

I believe this is a good budget. It is a fair budget. Overall, I believe the Northern Territory has done well considering the outstanding Beazley bankcard account. Territorians understand the problems the government has faced. Taking that into consideration, the budget is fair and territorians should be satisfied with the final outcome.

To reinforce this, I thought it might be worth while mentioning what the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Shane Stone, said in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly in response to the handing down in August of this federal budget. He said that it is a fair budget, that it will assist middle Australia, and that it is a budget that will help territory families, and he congratulated the Prime Minister. He continued:

. . . our Coalition colleagues in the Federal Government have gone about redressing Labor's mistakes by reducing expenditure rather than by increasing taxation, that is good news for all Australians. The average family out there in the Territory is going to do very well out of this Coalition Budget. We have had to pay the price, but we are doing it responsibly. We are doing it by reduction on expenditure and not by increasing taxation. John Howard is to be congratulated for that.

Getting back to the details of the budget and its benefits to the Northern Territory, the Northern Territory won in many areas as a result of the coalition's budget. In particular, the Northern Territory benefited in respect of defence, tourism, the diesel fuel rebate, the development import finance facility, the national landcare program and indigenous funding.

In respect of defence, I am particularly happy to see that there will be a further development of defence facilities in the Northern Territory. The development package is valued at $97 million for this financial year. This means that this year there will be an injection into the Northern Territory of around an extra $2 million each week. With such a strong commitment being shown to defence by the government, this should and will be maintained in the future. The federal budget allocated $484 million to major capital facilities for defence nationwide and the Northern Territory has been allocated more than one‐fifth of that total amount, showing territorians a true commitment from this government to the north and its development.

It was also pleasing to see that the export market development grants scheme has been retained. Small and medium sized businesses will be targeted with increased access for the tourist industry. The coalition government recognises the tourist industry's export potential, and increased the rate of the grant from the previous 25c to 50c in the dollar. An amount of $10 million over the next two years will be spent on a national program to provide incentives to the development of new tourism projects and facilities in rural and regional Australia.

Many of the measures announced in the budget and its increased focus on small and medium sized businesses that are exporting in the region will ensure that territory companies will be able to expand and thus increase employment opportunities in the Top End. Considering that tourism is one of our main industries, that is good news.

This government has shown its commitment to regional Australia with the maintenance of the diesel fuel rebate. This will benefit the mining, tourism and agricultural sectors. With these sectors playing a large part in the territory's economy and our development, this is good news and an astute decision made by the coalition government. There was a lot of speculation and misinformation being spread before the announcement that the diesel fuel rebate scheme would be maintained. I understand that the government will tighten the eligibility criteria for this scheme. However, keeping in line with the government's commitment to regional Australia, it was retained, and the speculation proved to be premature.

Although the development import finance facility program has been changed, I was very happy to hear that the concerns about the territory's Integrated Technical Services company were allayed. ITS is the partner and technical adviser to the solar power company Australia Solarex Pty Ltd. It had been proposed that the coalition government would not meet all of its DIFF commitments. To my knowledge, the coalition government is certainly meeting its commitment to Integrated Technical Services and Australia Solarex Pty Ltd which will help provide power supplies to remote areas of eastern Indonesia.

It is also welcoming to see the government's commitment to continue assistance to the 49 national landcare projects in the Northern Territory. The funding totals about $2½ million, and some of the major beneficiaries are land councils, Aboriginal councils and regional communities. The continuance of the national landcare program also demonstrates a major coalition commitment to rural Australia and, through these programs, the aim is to secure the long-term productivity and ecologically sustainable use of our natural resources.

Another fine example of the territory doing well in terms of budget savings is the funding of certain programs for Aboriginal Australians that have been quarantined from any budget cuts. Aboriginals represent a large portion of the Northern Territory population; in fact, they represent about 25 per cent of the total population. Aboriginal youth and families will benefit from the federal government's decision to save health, housing and employment programs from budget cuts.

The community development employment project, CDEP—otherwise known as the work for the dole scheme—has greatly reduced Aboriginal unemployment and given back to Aborigines their self-respect and self-esteem. It has also helped build much needed infrastructure such as roads, water and housing in remote communities.

The government has quarantined the health infrastructure priority projects, HIPP, and the community health infrastructure priority projects, CHIPP, from budget savings. The coalition is honouring its commitment to improve the outcomes for indigenous Australians, and I am pleased to see that these programs have been maintained.

Our predecessors ignored the situation for far too long, and indigenous Australia has been left with a shocking legacy. After those 13 long years of Labor government, living conditions in Aboriginal communities have not improved and, in some cases, have actually become worse.

The Commonwealth is also committed to spending a further $428 million over the next four years on specific indigenous programs. The programs' total Commonwealth funding for the next financial year will be $1.6 billion, which is the second highest on record. Our predecessor spent less in its last four years than this government plans to spend in its first four. The coalition government has handed down a fair and reasonable budget for indigenous Australia, and it has given top priority to maintaining the health, housing, employment and education needs of Aboriginals.

The coalition government has also brought in initiatives for general practitioners and specialists to support rural town services. The coalition is promoting and supporting the development of rural infrastructure and training of rural doctors. I know for a fact that, since the coalition government was elected, the territory has received many boosts to funding in health and aged care in remote areas. Under the family services portfolio, the territory has received funding to meet the needs of older territorians and to promote healthy ageing for Aboriginals and ethnic rural and remote territorians.

The 13 years of neglect of rural health issues is finally being addressed, and I for one am happy to see that this government is caring for those who live in remote areas such as the communities throughout the territory. The coalition government is not only a fair government but also a caring one. With regard to health in general, it is excellent to see the coalition putting in place initiatives such as the $1.5 billion private health insurance incentive. Who can forget when Labor's top paid politicians, such as Paul Keating and Carmen Lawrence, bragged that they did not take out private cover but relied solely on Medicare? Under Labor, private health cover declined by 33.6 per cent. The coalition government is setting about addressing that situation with the implementation of the private health insurance incentives whereby top earners and others will be encouraged to take out health insurance.

The coalition government has handed down a fair budget, one which is aimed at benefiting the whole of the Australian community, not just a privileged few. The government is committed to achieving tangible results, not just empty rhetoric, as was the case with our predecessors. One year ago the international financial markets judged Australia as a risk. They required a risk premium on 10‐year bonds of 2.2 per cent. That meant Australian 10‐year bonds had a 2.2 per cent higher risk rate than the United States. Since the election the risk premium has come down by one per cent to 1.2 per cent. Why? Largely because the coalition government's budget delivered what we said it would.

The government is working at getting the Australian government's finances in order. Our predecessors left Australia with a massive debt of $10.3 billion, one which the coalition government is committed to fixing. However, we will fix it in a far more accountable manner, and I know for a fact that we will not be shying away from the task that was left to us by our misguided counterparts. The Australian people wanted a change. They wanted someone who would govern the country in an accountable and sensible way. They wanted someone who would get on with the job. This budget certainly shows that the coalition government will be doing that.

I reiterate that I commend the government for its fair and sound budget, taking into account the $10.3 billion deficit left behind by the former Labor government. However, I must say that I hope to see some financial commitment from the Commonwealth next year for one of the most important things for the territory: that is, the Darwin to Alice Springs railway. I know there may be some initial financial outlay, which is difficult in this tough economic climate, but the long-term benefits to Australia and the Northern Territory economy would be enormous.

I would like to comment on a couple of points made by the honourable member for Watson. He said that the budget was for the privileged. I believe that it is a battler's budget. It is a battler's budget because it is about keeping interest rates down, which is most important. The budget is also about helping small business. If small business is stimulated, the economy will also be stimulated. Somebody said during the election campaign that if every small business in Australia employed one additional person there would be no unemployment. I believe that once the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) gets his unfair dismissal legislation through the Senate that will help everyone.

There is no nice way to recover a deficit of nearly $10 billion. The headlines in the media during the budget deliberations were very solidly in favour of the coalition's direction. The Labor Party is certainly not taking into consideration the direction that the government is taking. They were the ones that made the decisions over the past 13 years that resulted in the financial situation this country faces today.

This is a strong and fair budget, and I believe it will keep faith with the families. This coalition budget is about giving the Australian community a fair go. They know what kind of mess the economy is in. They know when they get their bankcard statement at the end of the month they have to pay it. Unfortunately, over the last 13 years the bankcard statement for Australia has never been paid.

We need strong medicine now. I know that some people in some sections of the community are going to complain, but I do not believe that any sections of the community should be quarantined from the measures that the coalition government is taking to try to get this country back on its feet. This budget is good news for the Australian community. I congratulate the Treasurer for bringing down the coalition's first budget in 13 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hatton, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This first Howard‐Costello government budget does, at last, show the coalition putting into practice what it really believes in. This is the National Commission of Audit, the coalition's primer and Fightback III package, in operation. The National Commission of Audit is the blueprint for the Howard years, and it provides the essential rationale, the actual focus and modus operandi, for the economic brigandage and social dislocation which are embodied in the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1996-97.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a budget of mindless negation. This is a budget of flippant destructiveness. This is a budget of supply side obsessions. This is a budget driven by the nihilistic ideological urge that lies at the heart of the coalition's philosophy: the urge to destroy a strong, central, unified federal government's involvement in the affairs of the nation.

The coalition wants to remake Australia in its own federally‐fractured image of itself. This coalition budget is the first step towards dismantling and dismembering the federal government and driving Australia back into a pre‐federation straitjacket of inconsequence and irrelevance.

The coalition firmly believes in the primacy of the states and the redeployment of any federal government programs or activities to those states. The coalition would return the Commonwealth to its position in 1901, when it only had a tripod of powers over posts, telegraphs, defence, customs and excise. The coalition would go further than this by handing over ownership and control of communications, and any other added areas of responsibility it can, to the private sector. The coalition's revolution is entirely minimalist. It seeks to destroy rather than build; it seeks to divide rather than cohere; and it seeks to diminish rather than enlarge.

This first Howard-Costello budget is but the first step in the coalition's march towards a diminished, divided and dissolved Commonwealth government of Australia. This budget is nothing less than a vigorous and concerted attack on the whole notion of Australia as a unified country preparing itself for a greater role in the economic affairs of the region and the world in the 21st century. This budget is directed at butchering this continent as one creative working nation and turning Australia into the dismembered nation.

This budget stands in stark contrast to the then opposition's deceptive presentation of itself as believing wholeheartedly in an entirely different approach to what it meant to be in government. This budget is the real coalition and not the pretend lot that we had before the last election. This budget is entirely consistent with the coalition's philosophical underpinnings, its view of the world, its view of this country and its understanding of the role of the federal government in Australian society.

This first Howard-Costello budget is merely the precursor of their future efforts, which will be directed towards a total reshaping of Australia as we now know it. Embedded in a 19th century understanding of the world, the coalition will attempt to refashion Australia into as anachronistic an entity as the coalition itself. This will result in the destruction of a strong, central, engaged federal government and the unity, purpose and sense of direction of continental Australia.

This first coalition budget seeks to hack and slash, cut and trim, burn and bury quality programs of real assistance to the people, businesses and regions of Australia. For all the asinine braying of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the pompous bleatings of mock outrage from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), retailing their supposed reasons for undertaking the dismantling of major programs, the simple stark reality is that this budget carves Labor programs to pieces and supplants them with the coalition's electorally-driven titbits.

This replacement process has been trumpeted by the Treasurer as taking place in the most transparent set of budget documents ever produced. In fact, these budget papers and the associated materials produced by various ministers' officers are the most opaque presentation of the budget in the history of the Commonwealth. The actual budget savings measures were almost impossible to identify because the government chose not to be up-front, direct, open and honest in the papers or the associated press releases.

The reason is not difficult to identify. The coalition did not want the media to be full of the actual details of all the cuts, because the public could then have been fully informed of the dramatic range and depth of the savings measures. The coalition thought it was politically smarter to either bury the information or simply not release it. Those sections of the public affected by the measures would only become aware of their direct impact over time as they were confronted with the increased costs and charges or the simple abolition of services.

This tactic made it almost impossible for the media to intelligently comment upon the real scope and impact of these measures. In the absence of hard and detailed information on the exact nature of the savings measures, the media was left to conjure with the broad outline of the figures and the coalition's rhetoric. The opacity of the papers is not confined to parliamentarians, the public at large and the media, but even to trained economists whose job it is to decipher the budget papers. A number of these economic specialists have commented that it is almost impossible to define the specific savings measures to be undertaken, because the information has simply not been provided.

This leads me to wonder whether the coalition government itself knows what those specific savings measures will be or whether they have just drummed the figures up on the basis of past Commonwealth government programs. Indeed, there would seem to be ample evidence for this view in the responses in question time of the Minister for Family Services, Mrs Judi Moylan, to opposition questions asking for specific details related to the savings measures propounded in the budget papers for her portfolio. The minister's recurrent, long-winded, rhetorical accounts of coalition policy did not answer the questions. That is not unusual, as coalition government ministers seem not to be given to the practice of answering the key details of opposition questions.

In the case of the Minister for Family Services, when repeatedly pressed for the detail, the minister seemed quite unable to reply. I think she just did not know the answers. Indeed, I think she still does not know because her answer in the House several weeks ago, when pressed yet again for the specifics, was simply to state that the budget figurings relied upon the costings of the former Labor government's hostels program. The obvious inference is that the minister does not know what the savings measures will be because they have not been worked out properly. They are just a guesstimate, and the coalition will make up the actual measures as it goes along.

This budget has dramatically cut federal government assistance to our exporters. This is generally illustrative of the broad thrust of the budget to deal the coalition government out of the proper business of the federal government. This coalition government has mindlessly and profoundly hurt businesses that can be the powerhouse of the future Australian economy's drive into Asian and world markets.

There were many Labor initiated programs designed to support the efforts of Australian companies in their drive for export opportunities. The export market development grants scheme is expected to save $82.3 million over the next four years by improved administration—achieved in part, no doubt, by reducing the eligibility of businesses for these grants and capping expenditure at $150 million. These measures are expected to save the budget $344.2 million over the next four years.

The coalition thinks that this cut in funding is a triumph, as the lamentable Minister for Foreign Affairs, the member for Mayo (Mr Downer), no doubt thinks that the abolition of the development import finance facility program is a diplomatic and trade triumph. For our small and medium sized firms trying hard to export into Asia, the arrant brigandage of these cuts will be totally apparent. The combined slashing of the EMDG scheme and the abolition of the DIFF scheme will, in the words of the Parliamentary Research Service's Budget Review 1996-97, `send negative signals to both Australian exporters and our trading partners because it has been such a high profile part of Australia's efforts to develop an export culture.'

PARA.BREAK: That export culture, which was nurtured by the previous Labor government, will be further diminished and constrained by the abolition of the International Trade Enhancement Scheme, the Tradeblazer Economic Commerce Project, the Australian Trading Enterprise: Japan project and the Innovative Agricultural Marketing Program. These were viable and successful schemes which enhanced the prospects of our small and medi um businesses in export trade. Their hacking and dismantling will directly affect those businesses which could have benefited from them and the export culture being encouraged by these programs.

SPEECH.PARA: Small and medium size companies need to be assisted to make a push into new markets overseas and bring back valuable export dollars. These companies have neither the resources in terms of their knowledge base or the money to pay for the costs to start up overseas. Unassisted, these small and medium enterprises will remain shackled, uncertain of how to proceed and too financially and experientially deficient to make the extremely difficult jump into an expansive exporting mode.

The previous Labor government's approach to assisting Australian businesses to export into Asia and the world was not a single focus program like the `supermarket to Asia' idea. Labor had a multilayered approach which understood the diversity of industry in Australia. These Labor programs recognised that every industry has the potential to export and provide income for the nation. By restricting businesses to one or two programs, as outlined in the report of the National Commission of Audit and the budget, this coalition government has gelded opportunities for the proliferation of Australian businesses into the global economy.

The reason for these actions is nothing short of an ideological push to remould this country using ideas and policies long discredited in others. The coalition government's direction, enunciated by the National Commission of Audit, is supposed to be based on choice, competition and efficiency under the aegis of the controlling mechanism of the marketplace. Everything else—whether direct services to the Australian population at large or federal government programs and instrumentalities—is given only secondary consideration and made subject to the coalition's marketplace and price signals mentality.

The federal government is not a corporation subject to hostile takeovers, acquisitions or mergers, but the coalition obviously thinks of itself as being in a receivership mode. The coalition—the grand receiver—is bent upon merging, if there is any discernible overlap, all disposable federal government functions and responsibilities with those of the states or local government, or is bent upon allowing federal government activities to be acquired by the private sector.

The National Commission of Audit precisely laid down the entirely minimalist guidelines for this receivership and the fire sale the coalition is conducting. The commission argued that the federal government should divest itself of all activities which were not part of its `core business', which the commission virtually defined out of existence except for a tangential monitoring and benchmarking role.

The commission believes that the government should fund programs but not actually deliver any services—they should be tendered out to public or private service providers. The federal government's prime role would then simply be to maintain and monitor through, in the commission's words on page ix of the preface:
. . . the use of benchmarking, competitive tendering, appropriate technology and cost recovery—
and by:
. . . setting up accountability and performance monitoring frameworks against desired outcomes.

For the National Commission of Audit and this coalition government, the federal government is reduced to the status of a supervisor or referee—it is not allowed to play the game because it is virtually relegated to being the sideline eye.

Government is about leadership and service. Federal government is about making one strong, unified nation and encouraging it to become economically and socially more cohesive and viable. It is not about creating six weak, divided, poor state based nations on the one continent of Australia. The federal government is not just the state's tax collector. It has had, in the past, a larger and more significant role in modernising the economy and the country, and it should continue to pursue and refine that positive interventionist role.

PARA.BREAK: No better example of the coalition's vicious ideological attack on programs of real conse quence—which demonstrate the federal government's ability to effectively innovate in the area of regional economic development in cooperation with state and local governments—is to be found in the axing of the Building Better Cities program. The success of Building Better Cities Mark I led the previous Labor government to announce Building Better Cities Mark II in the 1995-96 budget. This substantial funding was added to by Community and Nation and enhanced by Working Nation's $150 million regional development program. SPEECH.PARA: . . . allocated to regional strategic infrastructure and the remainder for regional economic structure, strategy and projects.

The core importance and the effectiveness of the efficient use of federal government funds in initiating projects, which would otherwise have never been started, is best demonstrated by the establishment of the Australian Technology Park in Redfern, Sydney. Under the direction of Dr Tom Forgan, $11 million of Building Better Cities funds were used to provide the basic infrastructure for this outstanding, perfectly located, world standard technology park. Without this funding from the Commonwealth, the Australian Technology Park would not presently exist. It would not have been built and would not be anticipating a stellar future in cutting edge research.

The coalition does not believe in direct funding of cooperatively based regional projects. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) justified the slashing and abolition of such regional programs in the following terms in his press release of 17 July 1996. He said:
Current arrangements for Regional Development and Urban management overlap with State and local Governments which have their own urban infrastructure and local Government reform programs.
There is no clear rationale or constitutional basis for Commonwealth involvement.

The minister for transport has lifted this straight from pages 77 and 78 of the report of the National Commission of Audit—the only change being a reordering of the sentences. One would have expected the minister to fully acknowledge his indebtedness to this coalition primer, but perhaps he did not want to draw attention to the direct source of the budget cuts in his portfolio. He surely could have because the National Commission of Audit, which is Fightback Mark III, is the full blooded sire of this Howard/Costello budget. The minister for transport should not have been coy about his indebtedness to the National Commission of Audit, because page after page of the budget papers directly lifts the wording of that document and its rationale, taking the government out of federal government across every portfolio area—none more so than in the infrastructure area.

The coalition government has followed the National Commission of Audit recommendations word for word but, when it comes to advice that is inconvenient, advice that does not fit in with its prejudices and advice that supports the former Labor government's innovative regional development program, it flatly refuses to take that sound advice. The McKinsey report, Supporting regional leadership: unfinished business, was dumped into the wastebasket because it said:

After only 18 months in operation, the Regional Development Program has made a significant start in rejuvenating leadership in Australia's regions. The Regional Development Program has the potential to make a significant impact on Australia's regions, and through them on national economic growth.
Further, it crucially found:

There is a continuing and important role for the Commonwealth in regional development, through continued Commonwealth funding; continued support for the Regional Development Organisation (RDO) structure; and continued coordination, data collection and dissemination of best practice.
The McKinsey report also found:

Just as (major projects funding) could be delivered jointly by State Governments and the Federal Government, we believe that others can only be delivered efficiently and effectively at the national level

The Australian Labor Party believes in building the Australian nation. The Australian Labor Party believes in infrastructure spend ing and its importance in revitalising the Australian economy and the country's regions.

The Australian Labor Party believes in the federal government's active intervention in the economic affairs of this country. The Australian Labor Party believes that major economic problems which affect the entire nation need to be attacked by the federal government and that innovative solutions to continental problems need to be sought. The Australian Labor Party believes that a strong, healthy, vigorous Australian economy and society cannot be achieved by a federal government which squibs its responsibilities or defines them out of existence.

The Australian Labor Party will argue against and oppose the dismembering of this nation and the effective dissolution of the federal government of Australia which has been blueprinted in the National Commission of Audit and which has found its first expression in this 1996‐97 Howard‐Costello budget—the manifesto for a coalition tragicomedy to be played out on the national stage in the coming years.

SPEECH.PARA: The budget betrays the Australian promise of working towards a more fair, inclusive and united society.

This statement is from a senior minister in a number of previous Labor governments: Labor governments that threw a million people onto the scrap heap in `the recession we had to have'; Labor governments that saw foreign debt go from $23 billion in 1983 to almost $200 million when they lost government; and Labor governments that planned for a cumulative deficit of $69 billion over their last five years. I will come back to that.

BREAK.PARA: The member for Holt was part of a Labor government that played favourites year after year, pandering to the minority groups whilst casting aside mainstream Australia. At long last Australia has a budget that is fair, that is just and that is inclusive. And it will unite society. The people, organisations, businesses, financial markets and community groups out there in the real world are telling us that.

No matter how much the Labor opposition runs around saying, `No, no, it is all dreadful, the world's about to end,' the people are saying otherwise. They are saying, `It is about time that a government was responsible.' They are saying, `We couldn't go on living beyond our means.' They are saying, `What you have designed is fair. It is just.'

The members of the Labor Party do not like it, do they, Mr Deputy Speaker? They do not like the fact that the people of Australia recognise that Labor totally mismanaged the finances of this country and that the people are thankful for the fact that, although we did not create the problem, we are prepared to take the responsibility for fixing it.

Let me reflect on the problem which I referred to. The budget papers clearly say that, in the last five budgets brought down by the former Labor government, an accumulated deficit of $69 billion was the result—and $69 billion is just another big number, some might say, but let us look at it in context. What an unbelievable situation. We have been growing, but we were going further and further into debt.

Over five years this means a turnover of about $700 billion with a loss of $70 billion. If that was a small business that turned over about $1.4 million a year—that is a small business that probably employs only a few people if it is in the retail area, or it might employ up to about 20 if it is in a service area—over a five‐year period of growth this small business turns over about $7 million. If this small business had a similar budget strategy to the previous Labor government's budget strategy, it would experience a loss of $700,000. Just think about that: a business in a growth period but budgeting to lose $700,000 in five years. That includes selling off some of its assets, if it really mimics the Labor government.

How long would that business stay in business? Not very long. The banks would be moving in pretty smartly. The Labor government did not last long either, once the shareholders realised what they were doing. They knew the banks were on the way, so they put new management in place in March—management that was prepared to address the problem, management that could put in place a comprehensive plan to sort it out.

There probably are not too many people on the other side of the chamber who can relate to the workings of a small business. Most only knew the workings of the Labor Party or the union movement. To help those opposite, let us look at the situation from the point of view of an individual's income.

Take an average family income of around $40,000 a year, which is not particularly high. Over five years that equals a total of $200,000. If that family ran their budget like the previous government ran theirs, they would build up a debt of $20,000—an extra $20,000 on the bankcard. They probably would have sold an odd asset as well—a bit of furniture or something like that. After five years, that family would be forced to do something drastic. They would not be able to keep putting it on the bankcard. Australia cannot continue to put it on the bankcard.

It is with that sort of background that this government put together the 1996 budget—a budget that turns that ever increasing debt around. Our budget is one of good financial management. It is yet another example of a coalition government having to clean up Labor's financial mess. Jeff Kennett had to do it in Victoria. Remember the rust bucket that Victoria became under Cain and Kirner? Dean Brown had to do it in South Australia. If Victoria was a rust bucket, South Australia under Labor became a mere pile of rust dust.

Labor governments just cannot handle money. They don't understand its value. It is simply numbers on paper to them. Labor's contribution to the debate on this budget further proves that. Opposition member after opposition member has stood up here and bleated about funding changes. In many cases, the so-called cuts are not cuts in spending compared to what was spent in previous years, but cuts compared to Labor's forward estimates from their last budget.

We know how far out they were in that budget. It was supposed to be in surplus, but it ended up being in excess of $10 billion in deficit. What does that say about their forward estimates? They were a joke. They were merely a wish list. Labor could not have stuck to their forward estimates because they were broke. So forget about making comparisons with Labor forward estimates. It is meaningless and totally misrepresents the reality.

Allow me to talk about the bleatings of those opposite, because it goes to the very heart of the philosophical differences between them and us. We saw the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) crying crocodile tears. It was the end of an era, he said. My oath it was—and thank goodness for that, say the Australian people. We had the member for Batman crying those crocodile tears about unemployment and Labor's beloved labour market program. He ruled over a union movement that sat back and allowed hundreds of thousands of workers to be thrown out of work by Labor's recession—a union movement that has contributed to an industrial relations system that has acted as the greatest disincentive to employment. We had the unfair dismissal laws, closed shops, sweetheart deals—all of those things.

Labor's solution to the unemployed that they created was to throw buckets of money around willy‐nilly on so-called labour market programs. I never did work out whether that was labour, L‐A‐B‐O‐U‐R or Labor, L‐A‐B‐O‐R. But I do know that, on the whole, that method did not work. It should have been part of Labor's environment policy because what it did was recycle people. In most cases—although, to give some credit, not all—it was an expensive, cynical method to fudge the books, to try to make out that things were going well. Each time an unemployed person went into one of the short‐term subsidised jobs, it was another job created as far as Labor was concerned. That is Labor's definition of job creation—welfare payments to keep someone off the unemployment list.

That is where we differ. Labor's solution is a socialist solution—people controlled by the state. Our solution is to facilitate the creation of real jobs. I said it in my workplace relations speech and I will say it again here: governments don't create real jobs. Only wealth creation and investment can create real jobs. But you will not get that unless your overall economic climate is right. That is the role of the government. Get the climate right and you will see confidence grow, you will see investment, you will see growth, and you will see real jobs being created. That is the problem with those on the other side. They used up lots of our assets, they borrowed more and more, and spent it all. They spent it by throwing it at schemes that were doing precious little for long-term jobs.

The real scandal in this regard is that everyone knew just how much was being wasted. Travelling around Eden-Monaro leading up to the election, I was continually told by labour market providers that so much money was being wasted. They told me that, instead of using money in a strategic way, the Labor government was simply writing cheques to move people off an unemployment list. But the net effect was minimal. In a spending frenzy, in a desperate attempt to get the numbers down by the election, they spent 95 per cent of the year's budget for labour market programs in their first eight months. Those out there in the marketplace knew it was happening and they were horrified. That is the sort of irresponsibility which is not in the budget we are now debating. You will not see that sort of wastage of public moneys by this government.

What we have here is a strong but fair budget for all fair‐minded Australians. The only squeals we will hear—apart from the squeals from our opponents opposite—will come from those minority and self‐interest groups that have been pandered to by the previous Labor government. The times of playing favourites are now gone and mainstream Australians will now get a fair go. Families in towns like Cooma, Bombala, Eden, Bega, Narooma, Moruya and Batemans Bay are very happy with this budget. Even before the budget, those families benefited from the interest rate cuts introduced since the coalition came to government. That has meant about $80 a month less for an average home loan repayment.

Under the budget those same families will benefit from the $1 billion tax incentive. Families in Eden-Monaro will benefit more than those in most other electorates because there are lots of low to middle income families in Eden‐Monaro. They are the ones who will benefit most.

I mentioned earlier that much of the so-called funding cuts were in fact only cuts in relation to Labor's forward estimates, not cuts in actual spending over the past years. The opposition and a few self‐interest groups have been working hard at creating the impression that a lot less money will be spent in certain areas, when in fact the truth is very different from that.

One of the myths that has been created since this budget was brought down relates to Aboriginal funding. We hear the figure of $400 million being thrown around as to how much less we are supposed to be spending in the area of Aboriginal affairs. Let us compare what Labor spent over its last four years in government with what we intend to spend in the next four years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I was interrupted for the dinner break I was commenting about Aboriginal funding in the budget being somewhat of a myth; and the sorts of things that have been thrown around since the budget explaining the differences between the previous government and our own. They are wrong. We are actually going to spend $4,955.9 million— $200.9 million more than was spent under the previous Labor government. So one might ask: what is the story? The parliamentary research service spells it out very well. In their budget review they say in relation to operating grants:

The reductions are equivalent to 1% in 1997, a further 3% in 1998, and a further 1% in 1999. It should be noted that these reductions are to the forward estimates, rather than to the current grants, and that the 1997 operating grants will actually be higher than those in 1996.

The Labor Party are exposed again because their forward estimates, as I said before, are a joke. How can anyone give credence to those when Labor were in excess of $10 billion out in their budget? They could never have met their forward estimates. So student activists best have a look at the reality and not what their ALP organisers are brainwashing them with.

While I am on higher education, I might make a few comments on changes to HECS. The reaction by some people would have you believe that we have introduced up-front university fees. That is not so. Those opposite, together with a few students from the Labor clubs at universities, have claimed that the change will make it harder for students from poorer families to go to university. What a load of rubbish! If we were introducing up-front fees, that might have some credibility, but we are not.

It is not like it was 27 years ago, for instance, when I started university when fees had to be paid up‐front. I came from a family who could not afford to pay for me to go to university. I worked after completing school and before university and started to put enough together to pay the first term fees. Fortunately for me I had worked hard enough at school and I won a Commonwealth scholarship which paid the fees but I still had to do plenty of after‐hours work to get some money to live on. But that was all pretty much the norm in those days.

Then we had Whitlam who said that university should be free to everyone. It then took the country some years to discover something that we all should know—that there is no such thing as a free lunch. In the process, however, researchers tell me that the demographics of university students did not really change during the free years, that is, there was no real increase in students from low income families.

HECS was introduced by a Labor government as a fairer system for the taxpayer, particularly those who did not go to university. Therefore, the changes in this budget simply ask those who get the benefits of a university education to pay a little more after they are finished if they choose and only when they are earning an income. It discriminates against no-one. It is fair. It is just and fair‐minded, and unselfish Australians will support it.

With regard to labour market programs, our emphasis is on targeted training. It is on apprenticeships and traineeships. It is on getting people back into real long-term jobs, not on dodgy schemes that rotate people from long-term unemployed to subsidised jobs back on to short-term unemployed. So the grandiose figures thrown around by Labor which purport to be cuts to labour market programs mean nothing. Firstly, they relate to their previous forward estimates and we already know they are a joke. Secondly, they ignore the change in emphasis.

In total, expenditure in the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs—let us concentrate on these figures—will be $17.817 billion in 1996-97. In 1995-96 it was $17.52 billion. This means we are actually spending $300 million more in that department this year.

Before I run out of time, I would also like to comment that this budget has been well received by the rural producers in my electorate. Eden-Monaro produces wool, lamb, beef and dairy, amongst other things. All of these sectors have been through very hard times with drought and low prices. Those producers appreciate that we will be spending $124 million under the rural adjustment scheme in 1996-97—$9 million more than last year. They also understand that the best thing that we can do for them is to get the overall economy right. They recognise that we are doing that with this budget.

As the member for Batman most eloquently put it, this budget marks the end of an era. It is the end of an era of governing only for minority groups. It is the end of an era of living beyond our means. It is the end of an era of waste. The families, the businesses, the communities of Eden-Monaro voted back in March to end the era of Labor's excesses. They knew the country could not go on in the way that it was.

They supported change to the management of the country's finances—a change that will see confidence return, a change that will see investment and with investment comes growth and then real long-term jobs. This budget sets the parameters to achieve the climate change required. It is supported in Eden-Monaro. I commend the 1996 budget to the House and reject Labor's amendment.

Specifically, there are a number of areas, about which I would like to tell the House to tonight, that demonstrate the extent to which these broken promises will impact in the broad community. I want to talk about those areas for which I have responsibility with the Labor Party in this chamber—that is, veterans' affairs, sport and tourism—but I also want to make mention more generally about a couple of other areas. The interesting thing about this government is that when they went to the last election they said, `What the Labor Party stands for, so do we.' It was all `Me, too,' in a modified form. They said that the regional development program which had been put in place was a great thing for regions. The amazing thing was, though, that the minister took the decision to give the regional development program the chop—$150 million worth of chop—before he got the McKinsey report. I have commended the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, most recently at the National Congress of the RSL, for maintaining direct benefits for veterans. I have commended the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in a bipartisan way for not only maintaining those benefits directly to the veterans community but also for actually getting some new programs funded in this budget. I am not sure how he did it, but he did well. Commemorative activities and a couple of other promises which were made have been funded. I have said publicly, and I will continue to do so, that he did a great job in that respect.

Regrettably, where he has not done such a good job is fending off the attack from his ministerial colleagues in the reform of aged care—or the terminology that his colleagues use—because the $26,000 average cost to obtain a place in a nursing home, the income testing of recurrent subsidies, which will add a maximum $238 a week, the increase in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and the increased user charges on home and community care, which are administered by states, will impact in the veterans community.

The minister's office has admitted it and the Department of Veterans' Affairs has admitted it but, for some reason, when I tried to draw out aspects of that particular matter in question time this afternoon, the Acting Prime Minister attacked our side of the parliament, referring to those of us on the front bench and me in particular, I think—because I could find no interjector in the Hansard report—as grubs. Yet here I was trying to defend the veterans community from the attack on them in this budget and to highlight to them the concerns that many of them have already shown to me as a shadow minister. And for my trouble I am called a grub by the Acting Prime Minister.

If I am a grub by name, then a grub by nature I will be. On the one hand, if I have to go to every RSL sub‐branch in Australia and tell them about the duplicity of this government, which trumpets veterans' affairs and says what terrific things they have done in the budget for them, I will do that. In a bipartisan fashion the minister and I have gone around Australia and talked about veterans' issues on a number of occasions now; and I compliment him because I believe, as I have said before, it is a bipartisan area.

On the other hand, if I believe that there are aspects of this budget which warrant an attack and warrant highlighting to the veterans community where I believe they are being disadvantaged, I will make no apology for bringing those issues to the attention of the veterans community. And I will do so, and will continue to do so.

The next issue which I would like to refer to briefly is the area of sport. Last week I participated in a grievance debate in this place where I expressed my concern about the budget decision in respect of the sporting portfolio. That was reflected in the allocation of funds to the Australian Sports Commission. Over the next four years there is going to be something like a $20.5 million reduction in the amount of money which is being made available to the Australian Sports Commission.

BREAK.PARA: As members in this place would know, the Australian Sports Commission is charged with the responsibility for allocating funds to sport in this country—not only for Olympic sports but for sport programs. Regrettably, the commission's hands have been tied behind their back by a government which does not see the benefit of sport, which does not see the improvements to lifestyle that come because of people being active in sport, and which does not see the benefits of teaching people a healthy lifestyle and, therefore, in the longer term reducing the amount of money that has to be expended on medical expenses and care; it has cut funding to the Australian Sports Commission.

So, rightly, the Australian Sports Commission, hamstrung as it is, said, `We have to make some hard choices. We have to fund only certain sports at the expense of others.' They took a decision that they were going to cut the vast majority of sports—make them go cold turkey with no funding from here on in. Part of that was for organisations like the Australian Schools Sports Council, the Confederation of Australian Sport—peak organisations of that nature which are charged with the responsibility of giving advice and representing the views of sporting organisations in this country. Talk about short‐sighted! And the criteria that were being used to assess whether some of these organisations warranted further funding, I think, need to be reviewed.

One example which I used last week, and I briefly refer to again, is recreational fishing. On the basis of the criteria adopted by the Australian Sports Commission in terms of participants in that sport and whether or not they are registered clubs, they decided that the allocation of some $77,000 for recreational fishing for the coming year could no longer be justified, and so they have cut it out. Recreational fishing maintains that they have a minimum of in excess of 200,000‐odd registered participants. How can that, therefore, be considered by anyone as not having the required numbers of participants to warrant continued funding?
This is an issue which recreational fishing is taking up with the minister, and I have recommended that they do so. It is also an issue which they are taking up with the Australian Sports Commission.

There are many other sports placed in a similar situation. But the one which stands out and which the rumours are still rife about is netball. Netball happens to be the women's sport which has the greatest participation level in this country. I do not think you can go anywhere in this country on a winter Saturday or, indeed, even during the week at night‐time indoors, and not see hundreds of females aged from about seven upwards playing netball. Yet, surprisingly, in this budget, because of decisions having to be taken by the ASC because this government has cut its funding base, there is a rumour around that they will maintain their base funding levels—at a reduced level—but they are actually going to cut the netball program out of the Australian Institute of Sport. We are only the world champions in netball! It is only the women's sport that has the greatest participation rate in this country! Yet a rumour is about that it will be cut from the AIS because it is not an Olympic sport.

That begs the question, as I mentioned last week, in this consideration of the sports budget of how much emphasis is placed on our Olympic sport and how much is placed on sport for all. I have taken the view, and I always will, that we must adequately fund the elite end of town. We must adequately fund the elite sports—those that are Olympic sports. I will always stand here and promote that view.

I also take the view that with the year 2000 looming, the decision taken by the government to maintain the $135 million commitment to Olympic sports participation over the next four years, which after all was only an extension of the former government's policy, was the right decision. I commend the government—I am not afraid to do so, once again, in a very bipartisan manner—for introducing the maintain the momentum program and allocating about $35 million towards it. That is great; that is fantastic.

PARA.BREAK: My concern is in respect of the balance that you strike between funding for Olympic sports and funding for the sport for all pro grams—things like the kids in sport program, Aussie sports, women's sport and Aboriginal sport. I take the point that in the case of Aboriginal sport, money has been made available for those programs, and that is only right too.

BREAK.PARA: Where the concern is in the broad sporting community, as is being brought home to me not only by people who have had their funding cut altogether but by those who have suffered reductions in funding, is how do you maintain the participation level of people if you do not have the wherewithal to sustain sport? You cannot always just say that it will rely on sponsorship and major companies to come along because, quite frankly, that just does not happen. Major companies will pick up the likes of the gold medal winners from Atlanta or some people who are in high profile sports who look good, or iron men or women or whatever it might be, but they will not pick up everybody. They will not pick up a sport and say, `We'll look after you because you haven't got any TV rights.' That is usually the major criteria as far as that is concerned.

I think there is a role for government in sport. There will always be a role. It is somewhat short‐sighted for this government to cut the funding for sport for all types of programs. I am not critical of the ASC for having to take the hard decisions that they have. I am not critical of them determining that some sports should not be funded. I take the view that some should not be funded in this country. We have about 18.5 million people in Australia these days. We cannot fund every sport that exists in the place; it simply is not possible. We will not make champions in every one of those sports. Simply because half a dozen people stand up and participate in something which they might do in Europe does not necessarily mean that we have a legitimate role to play in that. But I do think it is short‐sighted of the government to actually develop this idea that in some way we should cut sports funding other than at the elite end of town.

The final area in the couple of minutes I have left that I will refer to briefly—it is a subject I will be revisiting in the not too distant future—is in respect of tourism. The major promise which was broken there and which everybody is talking about in Queensland is in respect of the reef tax. A decision was made to impose a 500 per cent increase on the charge being levied per head on people going to the Great Barrier Reef under the guise that it is some sort of user charge and that it is environmentally sound to do so. That is nonsense. This government has decided to cut funding for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. In order to make up that shortfall they have said, `Let's increase the levy on people who are going there.'

The tourism operators in Queensland are going berserk—they are going ballistic—about this decision. Not only are they going berserk but, interestingly enough, so too are the coalition members who represent the Queensland seats affected by this reef tax. The tourism operators have all come and knocked on their doors and said, `What the hell are you doing to us? You actually came to Cairns last year during the election campaign and said, `Don't worry, tourism industry, there is no problem at all. We love you; you're going to be protected and we're going to give you plenty of money and there will be no problems at all.' That was a broken promise. Straightaway they introduced a reef tax. It stands out like you would not believe.

In respect of the tourism area more generally, the Australian Tourism Commission funding and the breaking of another promise, they maintained as an opposition before coming to government that they would continue to fund the Australian Tourism Commission at the levels previously enjoyed. That simply has not happened. There has been a cut there too. Australia's peak tourism organisation is charged with the responsibility of marketing Australia as a tourist destination. I think tourism is now our major export earner. They have had their funds cut; so they can only market in certain areas of Australia. They will have to revisit themselves. The new board that has only just been established after about three or four months of inactivity because the minister sacked the old board has to come to grips with this. It is about time the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) in this place actually gave some direction and showed how we should go. Quite honestly, this budget should be rejected. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, let me congratulate the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) for his commitment to sport. Whilst I may not have agreed with some of the content of his speech, it is easy to see his passion and commitment when he talks about sport.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Treasurer (Mr Costello) for a budget that was not easy to achieve. It is a budget which has finally acted in a financially responsible manner and a budget that has been directed not just to the vocal minorities but, indeed, towards the silent majorities—in other words, to the long-term forgotten Australians. This is a budget which will work for the long-term betterment of all Australians.

This is a budget which also addresses the problems facing our youth—problems that can no longer be ignored. Tonight I am proud to see the gallery full of young people from Clarencetown Public School, because the future of our nation is obviously dependent on the quality and care that we provide to the young people that we have in Australia.

Youth suicide is a subject that is very sad, one which I think touches us all. At some point in time, maybe a little distant, we will all know of someone who has experienced the tragedy of youth suicide, or any suicide, in their family or in their greater family group. With youth suicide doubling in the last 10 years in a nation that has an estimated 3,000 suicides per year in the 15‐ to 24‐year‐old age group—much more than the road toll figure—it is a very sad indictment of Australian society that it continues to allow this to happen. But what have they done? To be honest, nothing that amounts to much. They simply do not care. They have never cared.

I take this time to bring to the attention of the House a man who has had the courage to stand up and commit his life to mix and mingle with and, more importantly, not just hear but listen to these young people—Father John of the Commonstrength Foundation in Newcastle.
