He is an outstanding member of the society and a tireless worker in helping the youth of Australia. You may turn around at this point and ask what we have done to help prevent youth suicide. We have invested $19.1 million in the prevention of this sad indictment on society.

Last month I had the opportunity to meet with some of the youth in my local area of Port Stephens at a meeting of PEERS—prevention, encouragement, education, resource support—at the Port Stephens Council Chambers. Due credit goes to Janelle Pearce, the youth development officer at Port Stephens Council, for organising this night of poetry of youth for the children, and indeed to the workers of the PEERS program, Jenny Megson and Brett Harris.

They were working with some of the young kids that I had met—Whitey, Geordie, Wazza, Laura Porter, Sarah Manton and Cassandra Hockey. I listened to their poetry and tried to understand their problems. The difference between us and a lot of people from the other side is that we at least give the commitment to try to understand.

I would like to take some time to read some of the poetry. Whilst it may not be in the same vein as Wordsworth or others, I think that the message is a lot clearer. Geordie's poem, relating to street kids, has the title `Everything Sux!' It says:
Life sux, it's a drag when you are lonely and sad,
I want to be happy and glad but it makes me mad,
when Life stuffs me around I feel like a cloud weighed down and when it twists my tears drizzle down to the ground.
Whitey's poem titled `Death!' reads:
Death is a thing we all go through,
one day it's going to happen to me or you.
Nobody knows when they're going to go,
So live your life and go with the flow.
I don't care when I'm gonna die,
because I might be drunk or really high.
Maybe I'll get hit by a car or shot in the head,
but it doesn't matter because I'll be dead.
This is very, very sad. Sarah's poem, named `My Feelings Personally', reads:
I would like to run as far as I can
I need to get away
but no‐body understands
I'm not happy
but I once was
they think I'm still little
they don't understand I've grown up
I'm sad
I'm a misery
I've been like this
for a while
I can't run
I can't run as far away
I can't understand
why they treat me this way.
One of Sarah's poems, titled `Life', has been published in a book by PEERS called Crying out . The poem reads:
My life is a big tear
trying and trying to hear
listening to everyday life
of every single human being.
We might say that there
is nobody that knows
how empty you feel.
But there just might be,
Hopefully!!!
We hope they have learnt
to handle and cope.
Well, maybe it's just
a phase teenage
people go through,
and no matter what,
everybody survives.
We hope.

If our society took some time to listen to what the young people are saying and learned to listen to their language, to their message, we might start to understand the problems that they are experiencing.

It would be true to say that today there are a lot more pressures in life and expectations placed upon young people. It was easier for me and my colleague the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson), sitting beside me, to set goals when we were going through school because there were opportunities at the end, opportunities that have been denied to our children.
As I was reading through the book Crying out, I turned to the foreword, and in it was a quote from my colleague the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit). He said:
This worthwhile project in a book of poetry published by PEERS . . . is outstanding.

We need to sit and listen to these people. There is another side to this story which shows a bit of hope and a bit of enlightenment. In my role as a local member, I have been invited along to Girl Guide ceremonies. One of the things that I witnessed in those ceremonies, in particular on 6 June at East Maitland, was Emma Hunt and Kyla Douglas achieve the Baden-Powell awards. On 5 September, Marie Ann Healy, Sarah Morallis, Kylie Saxton and Janet Peters also achieved their Baden-Powell awards.

They are not easy awards to achieve. They require commitment and dedication not just from the participants but also from the parents to ensure that the biggest quality that is required is maintained—it is not just talent; it is stickability. Their parents indeed are to be congratulated.

Today we have led our youth to have a reliance on others and outside influences, such as electronic forms of media, for stimulation. In my research from getting around the electorate, I found a letter which I found quite encouraging. It puts the other side of the argument. It was an open letter to teenagers from a Children's Court magistrate. It says:
Always we hear the plaintive cry of teenagers: "What can we do? Where can we go?"

The answer is, go home. Wash the windows, paint the woodwork, rake the leaves, mow the lawn, scrub some floors, repair the sink, wash the car, learn to cook, build a boat, get a job, visit the sick and elderly, assist the poor, study your lessons, clean your room and when you are finished—and not tired—read a book.

Your parents DO NOT owe you entertainment. Your town DOES NOT owe you recreation facilities. The world DOES NOT owe you a living. You OWE the world something. You OWE it your time and energy and your talent, so that no-one will be at war, or in poverty, or sick, or lonely again.
In plain simple words, GROW UP, stop being a cry baby, get out of your dream world, develop a backbone not a wishbone, start acting like a man or a woman.

What you are God gave you. What you become you gave God. Australia needs your help for survival. You are important and you are needed. It is too late to sit around and wait for somebody to do something some day.
Some day is now and somebody is you. You be extraordinary, or we die.

Whilst some may interpret that as being a bit over the top, it has a very strong message. There has to be balance between the two. It is not as simple as taking one side of the argument or the other. The trick is remembering that we must work together. We must remember that we are part of a family unit and that we stand for family values, but neither should we place at risk any child no matter how small the risk. What price will we pay until we hear the cries in the dark, the sullen messages from these children? What will we do until this message is heard? Also, when will they listen to the words of wisdom? It is, after all, a two‐way street.

One of the big questions is: how exactly do we fix this problem? One part of the solution is creating jobs, creating hope, creating opportunity. People, in particular young people, need to feel as though they belong as a part of the society, as valued members of that society. Just yesterday, and indeed last night in this House, I outlined the launch of Hunter Beyond 2000, a tourism project which seeks to put the Hunter firmly on the map of tourism not only for its wineries but also for all the gems it possesses.

Yesterday, and as I said last night, that project has the support of the former minister from the opposition benches, David Simmons. He is working as part of a team. Teamwork is about achieving goals. As a team, they are not just chasing the domestic market; they are chasing the overseas market using the export market development grant that our government has had the foresight to expand to the tourism industry to make it easier to sell tourism offshore. Bringing in overseas dollars will not just reduce our budget deficit but will beat the domestic dollar some 10 to one for job creation in Australia. We need to support them so they can support us in job creation.

I will refer to another area about which we have heard much debate today—and I am glad to see the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) is across the chamber. One of the industries in my electorate that does employ a lot of people is the timber industry. I must raise the point that I am also very concerned about the New South Wales state Labor government. It is about to hand down its decision on the future of forestry in New South Wales and it has a propensity to follow in the footsteps of its federal counterparts.

The former member for Page, who was not so representative of his electorate of Page, who now graces the steps of state parliament as the member for Clarence, has had a Pauline conversion on the road to Macquarie Street. The man who sat back quietly and accepted the forestry assessment practice of 15 per cent, of locking up all the forests, has indeed changed his stripes. Now all of a sudden he believes in the timber industry. In the papers at least, he is standing up for the fight. But the fight is not in the papers; the fight is in the party room. I wish him well because we need to overturn it.

Today we have heard from the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) and the member for Burke with their views on the timber industry. They may not agree with me, but they are very narrow‐minded views without question. No wonder they lost the bush vote. Have they ever been to the bush? That is a question I posed today as I was interjecting—and I do apologise to the House for being rather rude in my interjections, but the bush is something I feel very passionate about, in particular the timber industry.

Have they ever considered what they will do to country towns like Gloucester, Dungog, Stroud or Bulahdelah, which are in my electorate? Have they considered that it is not only the timber industry that is affected but also the butchers, the bakers, the real estate agents, the child‐care centres, indeed the whole town? As we start to take away jobs, what goes next? The answer is the very fabric of society: the family unit, pride and respect.

PARA.BREAK: When I was on the campaign trail, I went to a mill and there was a worker there working his heart out covered in tannin, sawdust and whatever it was, but he was enjoying himself. What was he enjoying? He was enjoying the fact that he was making a contribution, the fact that he was working for a living. At the end of the week, he felt glad to take home his pay. That pay was just over $400 a week. I said to this chap, `How many kids have you got?' He said, `Mate, I've got four.' I said, `Are you paying off a mort gage?' He said, `Yep.' And I said, `How are you doing it?' He said, `I am doing it tough, but I'm a proud Australian. I'm proud to work.' To me, that man is 100 feet tall.

SPEECH.PARA: The bottom line is that those opposite do not care. They have never cared about the bush and, to be honest with you, the greatest reflection of that was in the polls at the last election. Some 31 seats in regional and rural Australia belong to my colleagues here on this side, the Liberal Party. My other colleagues in the National Party hold 18 seats in regional and rural Australia.

Boys and girls from Clarencetown Public School, up in the gallery, you do not have to be Einstein to work out that that leaves about one or maybe two seats in regional and rural Australia, and they sit in that little block over there. They sit over there because they do not understand, because they do not listen and, more importantly, because they do not care what happens to regional and rural Australia. They feign these approaches about policy decisions which they say are for the good of the bush but, let me tell you, they let them down.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the honourable member that he speaks through the chair when addressing the chamber.

—My apologies, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will address my remarks through the chair. Mr Deputy Speaker, today is a day from which we need to go forward, not backward. As I have said, one way we can resolve this problem is by putting people back into jobs. If those opposite wanted to earn redemption from the people in the bush, if they wanted to earn the respect of the people in the cities, they would support our industrial relations bill.

SPEECH.PARA: It is our industrial relations bill that will help put people back into jobs. To put it simply: if you cared, you would support our industrial relations legislation. If you wanted to see people back in jobs, if you wanted to see families relieved of stress, if you wanted to see personal pride restored across Australia, you would support our industrial relations bill—so that it too can contribute to reducing our deficit, enabling us to perhaps spend even more money on preventing youth suicide.

Those opposite will not support our legislation—and they will not support it because, in essence, they have shown themselves to be a destructive opposition. They are an opposition that obfuscates the issues; an opposition that likes to keep Australia on its knees—just as they have done for the past 13 years. This former government promised hopes, but shattered dreams. This former government promised prosperity, but increased poverty. This former government promised direction but, sadly, very sadly, lost the way. You can redeem yourselves now and, together, we can work to get this country going again to give all Australians a future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The impact of this mean spirited budget on the electorate of Scullin will be severe. The government has taken a gamble with the future of this nation, a political gamble that is based on the contention that `middle Australia'—however that is defined—does not care about unemployment. My fear is that that gamble has already failed and among the losers are my constituents.

SPEECH.PARA: The budget fails to deal with the most important problem that confronts this nation—the problem of unemployment. The budget contains no hope for the jobless. It predicts that unemployment will not fall. This is a crucial point.

Last week saw the government dissembling in its attempts to argue that unemployment will not fall unless it gets its policies through the Senate. However, based on the government's own assumptions contained in this budget, this budget provides for no fall in unemployment. At the same time, the budget rips $1.8 billion out of funding for labour market programs.

Understandably, many people have been attempting to comprehend the proposed labour market system without properly paying attention to the magnitude of the cuts in this area. Put simply, the most obvious effect of this massive cut is that no longer will there be a universal right of access to public assistance if you are unemployed. The effect of the cut next year will be that well over 200,000 unemployed Australians who were entitled to labour market assistance will not get access to that assistance. In the electorate of Scullin, this will mean that several hundred people will miss out on a place in programs that would have given them hope of rejoining the work force.

This is a scandal—and it gets far worse when you ask who gets a place and who does not. The answer to this question, which itself raises many questions, is that services will be provided to those with `a capacity to benefit'. How will `capacity to benefit' be defined? My fear and the growing fear in the community is that, in the end, it will be the most disadvantaged who will be found to have the least capacity to benefit. In other words, they will miss out. With those innocuous words `capacity to benefit', the government has slammed the door to the future shut in the faces of hundreds of thousands of Australians.

Many of the job seekers in the electorate of Scullin will presumably fall into this category. Many will be unable to enter the work force without the benefit of the programs they would have received under the previous system of labour market assistance. Let there be no mistake: we are not talking about isolated or extreme cases but about hundreds of thousands of people who will not get access to services because of the reduction of funds.

The new system, which comes fully into effect at the end of next year, is based on profit. The combination of the profit motive and vastly reduced total resources when labour market programs are cashed out will prove disastrous for those who are most at risk.

The government has gambled that middle Australia does not care about unemployment and the unemployed. Tradition has it that they are wrong. The tradition of a strong public provider of services for the unemployed in this country was inspired by national resolve to avoid a repeat of the devastating impact of unemployment during the Great Depression. This tradition was enshrined in the creation of the Commonwealth Employment Service in 1946.

BREAK.PARA: Fifty years on, the community does not yet fully understand that this tradition is about to be dismantled. They do not yet fully understand that, if they or a family member lose their job, they may well be told in Senator Vanstone's brave new world, `Sorry, you have no capacity to benefit.' The more that the reality of this wanton vandalism of a major plank of social policy becomes known, the more the architects of it will pay a political price.

In the electorate of Scullin, the unemployed are not the only victims of this budget. There can be no clearer example of an unjustified attack on the disadvantaged than the abolition of the Commonwealth dental health program. The former Labor government established the Commonwealth dental health program in 1994 because it recognised a tremendous need in the community that was not being met by the states, as indicated by increasing waiting lists and waiting list times.

Back then, the reality was that many disadvantaged people were not receiving adequate or appropriate dental treatment when they needed it. The Commonwealth program provided emergency and preventive care that helped unemployed people, pensioners and other people with health care cards. Care was provided in partnership from public, private and community providers. Figures provided by Dental Health Services, Victoria, show there were 5,395 treatments to card holders in 1995-96 in the federal electorate of Scullin.

However, the success of the Commonwealth dental health scheme in reducing waiting times for treatment was used by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) on budget night as an excuse for abolishing it. Does the Treasurer not realise that, without the Commonwealth program, waiting times will simply go back up? Pensioners and the disadvantaged will be back to waiting years for treatment. There can be no justification for cuts that affect people's health.

PARA.BREAK: In addition, this budget fails the first major test set by its authors—that is, honesty. This is a dishonest budget. It is dishonest at a number of levels. Firstly, it contains a litany of broken election promises. Not subtle or poorly defined promises, but clear, unequ ivocal commitments: `We will maintain levels of spending on Austudy.' But what does this budget do? It reduces expenditure on Austudy by $527 million over four years. `We will maintain expenditure on labour market programs in real terms'—but what does this budget reveal? It includes cuts in labour market programs of $1.8 billion. And on and on it goes. The list is breathtaking.

BREAK.PARA: People have ample cause to remember how the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) came to enjoy the nickname Honest John. The dishonesty of the budget operates at a more insidious level. It has been remarkable to hear the Prime Minister and the Treasurer prattling on about the so-called charter of budget honesty and, at the same time, claiming for these budget documents a degree of honesty and transparency that they clearly lack.

Let us take a couple of examples that expose the much vaunted charter of budget honesty as nothing more than hollow rhetoric. First, the example of the treatment of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, CSIRO. In the treatment of CSIRO, this budget shows these masters of creative accounting in full flight.

The government claims that it has recognised the importance of CSIRO—and so should any government—by increasing its funding by $115 million over four years. It claims to have more than honoured its election commitment to CSIRO. If only it were true. The other side of the ledger reveals the government's claims for what they really are.

The application of the increased efficiency dividend to all science expenditure will cost CSIRO $55 million over the next four years. The new tax on executive cars will hit CSIRO with a bill of an extra $3 million. Not content with these two attacks, buried within the revenue statement of Budget Paper No. 1 is the following little gem:
CSIRO will be expected to make efficiency gains in its operations and to rationalise underutilised property and assets over the forward estimates period.

This rationalisation totals an additional $60 million ripped out of its budget over four years. All the new taxes and charges that the government is imposing on CSIRO total about $13 million more over the four years than the extra funding. But what is the community told in the budget speech? The Treasurer said:

I am pleased to confirm tonight that the Government will honour its commitment to restore the CSIRO's baseline funding. The Government will provide an additional $150 million over the next 4 years to CSIRO.

This is breathtaking in its attempt to deceive. But this sort of behaviour does not end here. This is not an isolated example of the rhetoric getting away from the reality. Let us take another example. A budget fact sheet circulated by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) unequivocally and clearly states that there would be an additional $17.6 million over four years for English language training through the adult migrant education program—$17.6 million commencing the next financial year over four years for the AMEP.

If you look at Budget Paper No. 1, however, the forward estimates for migrant education over four years show a decrease of $1.1 million. Where is the extra money? The answer is that there is no extra money. There is no extra funding. It is nothing more than a shabby con trick. When the government announced a cut to the level of immigration in July, it adjusted the forward estimates for the migrant education program.

So, if we go to Budget Paper No. 1, page 3-87, we see the item `Reduction in migration places under the Humanitarian Programme—consequential reduction in English language education outlays.' The reduction for the current financial year is about $1 million and for the next three years it is minus $4.1 million, minus $7.1 million and minus $7.7 million.

By simply keeping the amount in the budget estimates roughly the same, actually down slightly from the Labor government's forward estimates, they have attempted to pass this off as an increase. In other words, slightly less money is being spent. There is not an additional $17.6 million at all.

PARA.BREAK: At the same time, because the government has massively increased the user charges that apply for migrant education, it is the migrants themselves who are paying to keep the fund ing at about the same level. In fact, the revenue from these increased charges—buried deep in the budget papers like the slug on CSIRO—will recoup $28 million for the government over the next four years.

BREAK.PARA: I refer honourable members to Budget Paper No. 1, page 4‐6, where it says `Increased cost recovery in the adult migrant English program'. The estimated changes in revenue in the year 1996-97 will be plus $3 million. For the next three years it will be plus $7 million, plus $9 million and plus $9 million.

In another budget table, not identified as containing information relevant to the program in the index, you find, `Adult migrant English program property efficiencies—reduction in property operating expenses,' minus $4 million over four years. In the same table you find the line that I have already read out: minus $19.9 million over four years. These are facts that are not found in the fact sheet.

So much for this much vaunted transparent document. This is obfuscation of which Dr Goebbels would be proud. So much for the charter of budget honesty: cut immigration, increase the charges for those who do get in, and call that an increase when the forward estimates show that the amount that is going to be spent is less.

But the reality is that the community providers and community groups are taking the minister's fact sheet about budget measures at face value. They are expecting increased funding and are planning on that basis. Clearly, all Australians should read this budget's fine print. For this government, there is honesty and budget honesty. That is just like there are promises—core promises and non-core promises. They are new additions to the political lexicon. This government sets itself up as the paragon of virtue and integrity. The charter of budget honesty is in tatters before it has even been tabled. Honesty was the first casualty of the Howard government, but it is not the last.

It is incredible that the government continually claims that the changes to the Australian industrial relations system are going to instantly lead to new employment growth. The evidence from Britain, the United States and New Zealand is that the terrible price of so-called labour market flexibility is great social inequality. An analysis of commentators' views on the effects of industrial relations flexibility on employment reveals one thing: even where the commentators differ in opinion, they agree that the effect is overwhelmingly negative. The conclusion is either that it has absolutely no effect on employment growth or that any new jobs that result from wage flexibility are so low paid that the gap of social inequality simply widens.

For example, there is an army of the working poor in the United States. This is approaching some 11 million American workers. They are battling on the American minimum wage of $US4.25 an hour—the equivalent of $A5.30. Of these 11 million workers of the working poor, 40 per cent are the sole breadwinners for their families, struggling to get by with the minimum wage and the very poor social benefits afforded to them in the United States. The United States industrial relations system means that unskilled and low paid workers receive significantly less than their counterparts in any other developed nation. All evidence suggests that employers put on workers based on the expected demand for their goods, not based on relative wage levels. In fact, cuts to wage levels can dampen demand and further undermine the economy.

It is regrettable that arising from this budget there is a growing degree of anxiety. People are unsure in reality what the future holds. Notwithstanding what those who sit opposite say, that is the reality. We find that many groups that have provided community services from time to time, because they have to enter into the competitive nature of tendering for programs, have become distrustful of each other. The wide networks that have grown are disintegrating because of this competitive nature. Rather than bringing efficiency within the system, it brings inefficiencies.

Those who find themselves doubtful of what their employment future holds are anxious. Those who have been planning new business ventures are also anxious, because it is unclear to them what the government's intentions are in encouraging the new types of industries that will be required within Australia to bring job growth.

In my electorate there have been plans on the board to put together an automotive components technology park. Many businesses and local tertiary institutions have been working on this. Because of the uncertainty of the environment that has been put in place by the Commonwealth government, they are unsure of what the future holds for the plans they have.

There can be no clearer evidence than this iniquitous budget that the government has failed to deliver on its promise to govern for all Australians. The budget targets the less well-off and the most needy: the sick, students, the aged, migrants, the unemployed. It contains a blunt message to all Australians: if you cannot pay, you will miss out. As the details of this budget are explored, it is becoming increasingly obvious that it represents a sustained and comprehensive attack on the fabric of our social safety net. The message is: if you cannot pay, you miss out. This is not the sort of society we want. People did not vote for this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vale, Danna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The budget handed down on the evening of 20 August 1996 by the first Liberal government in 13 years was heralded as a budget which delivered for all Australians. The headline in the Daily Telegraph the following morning called it a `fair go budget', and to me this best describes the measures by which this Liberal government will deliver the strong economic management promised to the people of Australia before the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: The budget is a fair go budget because not only are the measures taken mindful of the tough choices that come with tough economic responsibility but they are taken with a finely honed sense of social awareness that has been historically evident in coalition social policy. At the heart of coalition social policy is its concern to protect those in the midst of our Australian communities who are the most vulnerable.

For those who need to be reminded of the social innovations of previous coalition governments, the introduction of the old age and invalid pension, assistance for deserted wives, the introduction of rent assistance and the provision of additional support for low income families are but a few of the significant initiatives of social responsibility which reflect the strong commitment of the coalition government.

The coalition parties have always valued the families of our nation and in this budget have shown their strong support for the critical role that families play in the nurturing of the Australians of the future. This government recognises the costs associated with raising children and has provided positive assistance for those on low and middle incomes by the introduction of the family tax initiative. This positive measure of support for families also includes consideration of lone parent families which suffer a high incidence of poverty. In practical terms, this means that under this budget lone parent families with two children—one under five years of age—will receive $34.64 a fortnight. It should be noted that last year Labor's assistance to families in this situation was only $4 a fortnight.

The budget has provided benefits for our senior Australians by keeping the age pension benchmark at 25 per cent of average total male weekly earnings and indexing the pension rate twice a year. Reforms to the youth allowance and the apprenticeship training scheme testify to the real concerns this government has for our younger Australians and recognise the very real difficulties for many young people who are trying to obtain real jobs.

The new apprenticeship training scheme is an exciting innovation to allow vocational training courses to be offered by local high schools. The government will make available $167 million over the next four years to encourage local high schools to offer practical opportunities in vocational courses to students. It is envisaged that the courses will be industry based and students completing such courses will receive accreditation, which should provide positive assistance to them in gaining meaningful employment. This innovative reform of job training and education will provide a very real and practical measure in addressing youth unemployment and hinges on the passage through the Senate of the workplace relations bill.

It is fair to say that this government has, with a clear and unsullied focus, placed the welfare of families on the high side of budget priority. This concern has provided the fulcrum upon which economic responsibility has been balanced and, to its great credit, this coalition government has succeeded where Labor has failed. This is the fair go budget that Australia has been waiting for for 13 years. But Australia is still waiting. We are still waiting on the Senate. Australia is holding its breath waiting for the Senate to allow the passage of the government's legislative program which, when passed, will provide the national economy with enough muscle to tackle the national deficit head on, which will provide the best security for all of us.

That this government has at its heart the support of the families of the Australian nation is one aspect of the pride that I feel in being part of John Howard's 38th parliament. In an age where relationships of all kinds are under tremendous stress, the family is certainly taking a buffeting in modern Australian society. More often than not, mothers are now forced into the workplace to help provide the family income. Their role is increasingly difficult and increasingly stressful.

The role of the modern woman has changed from that of wife and mother and homemaker to include breadwinner. Even if she would choose to stay at home to be a full‐time parent for her young children, the modern woman has little choice. She sooner or later succumbs to the economic imperatives imposed by the reality of life in Australia in the late 1990s. She soon returns to the work force to help provide the family mortgage or to pay the family bills.

One of the tenets of the feminist ethic of the sixties was the essential freedom of choice for women. However, since that time the thought often strikes me that, despite some significant gains, all women have really achieved has been the right to be eternally tired. Therefore, I soundly welcome the initiatives of the family tax package, and I am grateful that this government has the wisdom to support all women in recognition of the very real contribution they are all making to this nation.

The government's reforms in the workplace relations bill will provide very real assistance to those in the small business sector who are best placed to employ those presently unemployed. This is an important reform initiative of the coalition government and another which is in the bottleneck of government bills waiting in the Senate.

My electorate of Hughes is unusual in that it does not have a major town or city as the focus of its economic activity. There is no one locality which provides a pulsating corporate heart, as there are in other electorates. What we do have in Hughes are thousands of small businesses, many of which are family businesses. Retail proprietors in the many shopping centres of the suburbs throughout the electorate are well represented, as are small service enterprises, engineering and small manufacturing concerns. All share one thing in common, and that is an urgent need for the creation of an economic culture which understands the problems faced by small business.

The government's legislation will be instrumental in creating the kind of economic culture looked for by small business, and waiting for the Senate to deal with the very unfair dismissal laws is one of the major concerns of the small business sector. Many small businesses in my electorate have been reluctant to employ new staff due to the unfair dismissal laws of the previous government, and they are looking to the Senate to give them the green light to get going and to get serious about employing again. They, along with the rest of Australia, continue to wait and wait on the Senate.

During the delivery of his speech on budget night, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) clearly articulated the tough commitment this government gave to the Australian people. His comments bear repeating and repeating often. We need to be reminded that the previous Labor government had this country on the path of deficit and debt well into the next century. We also need to be reminded that, although the coalition government did not create the problem, the coalition government has totally accepted the responsibility to fix it.

This alone is a very powerful commitment from the government to the Australian people. The Australian people have been waiting far too long for a government with sufficient intestinal fortitude and an appropriately disciplined mind to make the tough political decisions necessary to deal with the deficit. However, the Australian people are still waiting to secure the strong economic benefits which will flow from those tough political decisions by the coalition. They are still waiting on the government's legislative program to be passed through the Senate.

The Liberal coalition was given a mandate by the people of Australia to make those tough political decisions so that all Australians will have a more secure future. This was the mandate for all of us. So now let the eyes of Australia firmly focus on the Senate. We will wait and see how far the Democrats, the Independents and the Labor senators will go to deprive Australia of the economic benefits delivered by the coalition government on behalf of all Australians, because this was, indeed, the budget which held families in high regard and clearly delivered for all the families of Australia.

It is therefore of particular concern to me that those families in my electorate of Hughes are in a peculiar position of economic uncertainty shared by no other group of families in Australia. This is because of the possibility of an airport which may be built within the proximity of their homes. As has been articulated many times since we have established government—and will, undoubtedly, continue to be articulated by our leaders into the future—this government stands up for families. It is therefore with a mind very much alive to the promises made at the last election that I draw the attention of this honourable House to the plight of the families in my electorate of Hughes.

The families of my electorate are currently living with the possibility of having an airport constructed within their backyard—not just an ordinary little airport, but an international airport. This has raised great anxiety and distress amongst the families in my electorate and in the adjoining communities in an area which is one of the fastest growing residential areas of south‐western Sydney. The families of the suburbs of Wattle Grove, Holsworthy, Hammondville, Moorebank and Chipping Norton have already felt the impact of the proposal. The impact is not caused by aircraft noise, nor increased traffic, nor the negative impact on the neighbourhood amenity caused by the close proximity of an international airport; the impact is devastatingly financial.

The impact has caused devaluation in property values in the western end of the Hughes electorate which occurred immediately it was announced that an EIS was to be done on the Holsworthy defence area. I have been informed by constituents that some have lost up to 20 per cent of the value of their family home, which in most cases is the only real family asset. This impact has been devastating for those who have had to sell their homes in the short term. It has been devastating for those who were trying to refinance their homes or who were using their homes as collateral in a business. It is devastating for them to find that the value of their property has dropped tens of thousands of dollars overnight on the basis that Holsworthy may be considered as the site of Sydney's second international airport.

That tens of thousands of residents in Hughes made submissions on the EIS guidelines—as did many individuals and community groups from the area—is indicative of the very real distress and concern shown by my constituents. Their very real concern is also derived from a common awareness of the questions which surrounded the EIS for the third runway at Kingsford‐Smith airport. They share an anxiety about the time frame allowed for the Holsworthy EIS process. They are understandably concerned that the six months allowed for a project of this magnitude is insufficient and that their rights to full and comprehensive environmental protection may be in jeopardy.

Proper environmental assessment and management of the EIS process is essential as this proposal will encompass the last area of significant bushland in the outer Sydney metropolitan area. This bushland includes the Holsworthy defence area, Heathcote National Park and the Royal National Park. The environmental interests of future generations are as important as the economic needs of the present generation. You and I, Mr Deputy Speaker, are the custodian generation, and we have the precious custody of a unique area of bushland which is a wealth of remaining biodiversity. Here is an untapped resource of immeasurable benefit to the people of New South Wales. We are accountable for how we deal with it. It would be the sacrilege of the century to sell it off for 30 pieces of silver to become an international airport.

Not all of the Holsworthy area has been affected by the defence artillery range. The Holsworthy area also holds a wilderness of remarkable beauty. The deep ravines, some deeper than 60 metres, create a topography of corrugated grandeur resplendent with the same kind of Australian bushland which provided such wonderment to Sir Joseph Banks over 200 years ago.This is Holsworthy: a secret wilderness of the Sydney Plain left almost intact from modern civilisation despite 200 years of European settlement. Six months is not sufficient time for an environmental impact study to deal fully with the collision of the 21st century upon this ancient secret wilderness. The present EIS process cannot hope to do justice to this largely unstudied natural resource within the limits of a six months time frame.

At the present time, the preferred option of the government is stated to be Badgerys Creek. However, this is difficult for my constituents to understand when the two sites will be compared in the same EIS and the land at Badgerys Creek is far too small for the ultimate scale of an international airport. This conclusion makes the resurrection of Holsworthy a more risky planning decision, because picking winners—as shown by the Kingsford‐Smith third runway—is bad planning process. Rather, the `sieve analysis' planning method used in 1985, which dismissed Holsworthy early in the process, is a world recognised site selection method.

PARA.BREAK: Another important issue which surrounds airports is that of noise, and this is where local knowledge of an area must be communi cated to those who will make decisions at some distance in Canberra. It is known by the people who live in the Sydney region that temperature inversions are a common occurrence, especially in summer, autumn and spring. A temperature inversion is created when a layer of colder air traps a layer of warmer air underneath. In the Sydney basin inversions are usually about 300 metres above ground level. However, Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw this to your attention because it is very significant. There is an atmospheric phenomenon at Holsworthy above the defence area where temperature inversions have been recorded as low as 50 metres above ground level.

SPEECH.PARA: The significance of this is that a temperature inversion acts as a kind of sound amplifier. The Department of Defence is well aware of temperature inversions and, in deference to its civilian neighbours in the converging residential areas, now refrains from artillery practice on the Holsworthy artillery range when an inversion is present. The Holsworthy artillery range is part of the very same area under consideration as a site for an international airport.

As a child living at Sylvania in the Sutherland shire, I can recall hearing the guns being fired on the artillery range at Holsworthy. All of Sutherland shire could hear the guns from Holsworthy. As a matter of fact, I am reliably informed that the guns could be heard from the Kurnell Peninsula in the north‐east, down to Helensburgh in the south, when an inversion was present over Holsworthy. I am also told that the guns could be heard in the Southern Tablelands and up around Windsor and even Hornsby, well to the north of Sydney. Now that the army has established a new protocol whereby the range is not used for firing practice when an inversion is present, the guns are hardly heard at all in the Sutherland area.

Temperature inversions cannot be controlled. They cannot be turned on and off. The noise of international passenger jets doing their pre‐take‐off checks on the tarmac would be heard as a roar all over the Sydney basin. Not only will the noise of departing international passenger jets at 30‐second intervals with all engines at full take‐off thrust be heard from Hornsby to Helensburgh, but also it is likely to send us all quite mad within a week. When a temperature inversion is present 50 metres above the runway on Holsworthy international airport, there will be precious little escape from aircraft noise for any man, woman and child living in the Sydney basin.

In deference to this budget debate, there are the financial aspects of this project. We are talking in terms of billions of dollars when we speak of building an international airport. In the light of this government's sound budget responsibility and its readiness to take the tough decision on behalf of the future generations of Australians, I wish to express my concerns and those of my electorate regarding the fact that the financial feasibility study which will be undertaken with the EIS will be completed without any input from, or consultation with, the community.

One has only to look again at the experience of the Kingsford-Smith third runway. The cabinet‐in‐confidence cost‐benefit analysis in 1989 for the third runway got it terribly wrong. This resulted in vast dollar costs to the public and airline industries in lost efficiency. This flawed cost analysis is in danger of repetition in Holsworthy, with an essentially confidential feasibility study. For the government, one important attraction of Holsworthy is that it already owns the land upon which the airport may be built. However, there are other important cost considerations which have an unknown inherent dynamic set to spiral costs out of control.

One would think the cost of building an airport proper could be reasonably assessed from the design and construction required for its completion. Yet, historically, similar projects of like magnitude have been subject to massive cost overruns; for example, the Darling Harbour project, the Sydney Opera House and, indeed, this very honourable House itself.

There are other issues which cannot be so clearly assessed. For one, the removal of the unexploded bombs from the artillery range, the result of over 100 years of artillery practice, defies a ballpark cost estimation. This is because no‐one knows exactly how many unexploded bombs are out there. I am assured that modern technology developed in the Gulf War has now provided the means by which unexploded bombs may be removed. However, the cost of such removal will not be known until the last blast of the last bomb.

Further, the costs of removing and relocating the Defence Force must also be put into the equation. The government should also rightly consider the economic impact of the removal of Defence Force personnel upon the local business community. In my electorate alone, this proposal will directly affect 30,000 people, who are mostly hard‐working middle‐ class Australians with young families.

There is a wider area of Sydney which is also involved, including the Sutherland shire, Bankstown, Hurstville, the St George area and the south‐western districts of Liverpool, Camden, Campbelltown and Helensburgh. Some of the area's newest and most significant residential areas of Wattle Grove, Chipping Norton, Lucas Heights, Menai, Woronora Heights, Heathcote and Engadine are contiguous with the Holsworthy area.

With great respect, and being mindful of the tough decisions made by our government in acceptance of full financial responsibility for the future of this nation, it is a key point that our government also has an obligation to be seen to properly manage the financial aspect of a project of this magnitude.

If our government does not see any wisdom in allowing community input into the financial feasibility study for the Holsworthy proposal, perhaps our government would allow the completed financial feasibility study to be tabled in parliament so that the elected representatives of the people may be informed of the significant costs involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share the dismay of the honourable member for Hughes (Mrs Vale) at the shabby way in which the Liberal government has treated her and her electorate and at the way in which they have abused the trust which her voters placed in her at election time. But, as this budget shows, that is no different from the way this government has betrayed all those who voted Liberal back on 2 March.

BREAK.PARA: First, the government has run up the white flag on jobs; we have seen an abject surrender in the fight against unemployment. The government has no targets. What did it say before the election? Let us look at the Liberal and National parties' youth policy, which was released in February this year. It is titled `Giving hope to our young'. It says:
The Liberal and National parties believe that addressing the unacceptably high levels of youth unemployment must be the first priority of the next federal government.

Not the second, not the third, but the first. They said that their priority was not deficit and debt, not selling Telstra, not attacking unions, but `addressing the unacceptably high levels of youth unemployment'. The policy document went on to state:
We will implement a strategy to accelerate the rate of job creation. We will increase job creation by getting government off the back of small business. . .
Malcolm McGregor put it very well in the Financial Review of 14 August, just a month ago, when he said:

Of course, from John Howard right down the conga line of mediocrities to David Kemp, they campaigned as champions of unemployed people, especially the young. Liberal crocodile tears were shed in abundance about the shocking level of youth unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is out of order to refer to members by name.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. But what does the budget do to reduce unemployment? Absolutely nothing. And it will simply make unemployment worse. First, the budget speech of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) barely mentions unemployment. Second, the government refuse to set targets for unemployment or for job creation. They will write to the Reserve Bank and set a target for inflation. They will set targets about small business paperwork. But do they care enough to set a target for unemployment? Not on your life.

BREAK.PARA: Third, if you look at the budget papers you will see that they are predicting that unemployment will still be 8¼ per cent next June, with no ground for optimism for any improvement thereafter. The budget papers also make it clear that growth under this government will not exceed 3½ per cent and will be just 3¼ per cent next year.

To get unemployment below its present unacceptable level, growth has to be maintained at four per cent or better. That was Labor's record for the past five years. We set a target—five per cent by the year 2000. We were well on the way to meeting it, but since the Liberals got in unemployment has started to rise again—up to 8.8 per cent last week. That is not surprising.

First, the Liberal government have talked down the economy, talked down confidence, with their self-serving rhetoric about black holes and mass sackings. The chief executive of the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies put it pretty well. He said:

On this occasion, the Howard government has allowed a very unhealthy economic climate to develop. They have created investor uncertainty by allowing public speculation to drive the debate over a considerable period.
He said:

They have promoted the view that there is an $8 billion black hole in the budget when in fact many observers are of the opinion that it is an election promise black hole which they are trying to finance.

Secondly, they have slashed labour market programs. Working Nation had played such a key role in getting unemployment down—in my own electorate of Wills unemployment fell from 20 per cent at the height of the recession to 10 per cent more recently—but they have taken out $1.8 billion over four years from the Working Nation programs. Thirdly, we have seen a dramatic program of public sector job slashing and job exporting. Telstra, just a few days ago, announced a $2 billion profit, yet it is going to cut jobs by over 20,000 over the course of the next three years.

These policies are damaging job prospects and damaging our economic recovery. What has the government got to say in defence of itself? There are two things. First, it says, `Give us our policies. Let us have our way. Let us get our way on industrial relations. Let us sell a third of Telstra. Let us get our budget through this House, through this parliament, with all its broken promises. Let us get our budget through unscathed.' But let us look back at those budget papers—8.25 per cent unemployment by June next year. So we have a government which does not believe itself. It does not believe its own rhetoric—8.25 per cent by June next year.
Secondly, and in a sense even more sinister, as Malcolm McGregor's Financial Review article points out that the government is reverting to the rhetoric of the Fraser era. The article states:

Nothing better illustrates this return to the dole bludger stigma than the so-called dole diary. Unemployment is no longer the deliberate and personal creation of Mr P.J. Keating . . . No siree, now it is a manifestation of the mendacity of unemployed people themselves.
Mr McGregor says:
Perhaps Senator Newman could explain to us why these epidemics of wanton idleness only occur shortly after the election of Coalition Governments.
So Labor's plan to get unemployment down to five per cent by the year 2000 has been abandoned and the Liberal Party has run up the white flag of surrender regarding unemployment. It has given up.

Its economic strategy is quite wrong. It will run down the economy. It will slow economic growth. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer are saying, `Everything will be okay once we deal with deficit and debt. Then we can have decent community services. Then we can have decent social support.' But we will never get to that point under their policies. It will always be just out of reach.

Secondly, if they do deliver a budget surplus it will go back to Liberal friends. In Victoria, Premier Kennett has now recorded a $5 billion surplus, mostly thanks to privatisations, jacking up taxes and charges, gambling revenue and so on. Now he says that that money is going to go to cutting business taxes, upgrading the Victorian Parliament House, the Albert Park grand prix, the bid for the Commonwealth Games and the like.

He attacked those who were not well off. He charged a $100 state deficit levy; there were massive increases in electricity, gas and water prices; 300 schools closed; country rail services closed; and hospital services were crippled. He blamed all that on Labor, but now that there is a $5 billion surplus does any of it go back to transport or to schools or to hospitals? No, it goes to friends of the Liberal Party. The same thing is going to happen here. The cuts and the hardship are to be blamed on Labor but the money saved will be spent on funding government election promises like the private health insurance rebate which is even now going straight back into the pockets of the private health insurance companies.

I suppose what narks me even more than the fact that the government has surrendered in the fight against unemployment, galling though that is, and the fact that its economic strategy is the same as the failed strategy that Thatcher tried in Britain which has given that country greater levels of inequality than anywhere else in the Western world, galling though that is too, is this government's cynical regard for the battlers—those people whom the Prime Minister courted so ardently before the election.

What does this budget do to them? We have seen the dental health program abolished, which will affect some 6,400 people in my electorate of Wills who used that program during the past financial year. The labour market programs have been cut—those programs which halved unemployment in Wills from its peak of 20 per cent to 10 per cent more recently. Community legal services have been cut by $33 million. HECS fees have risen so that the cost of tertiary education per year per student has risen from some $2,200 to over $5,000 for some courses. At the same time the repayment threshold has been lowered from $28,000 to some $21,000.

The child‐care operating subsidy for community child‐care centres has been cut. Parents will have to find an extra $20-odd per week per child if they are to continue sending their child to child care. Worst of all is the introduction of nursing home entry contributions. The amount of $26,000 has been suggested as an average nursing home entry contribution. For many people who will have to put their parents into nursing homes at some stage the fee will be a lot higher.

So John Howard's battlers are very unusual. They have a perfect set of teeth. They never have any problems getting a job. They never get into trouble with the law or need legal advice. They never aspire to send their kids to university. In fact, they do not even have any kids. They do not have parents either. I say to Australians out there that, if you are a perpetually healthy, fully employed, legally trained, childless bastard, you may still qualify as one of John Howard's battlers.

The alternative explanation, of course, is that the Prime Minister has betrayed thousands of voters, even tens of thousands of voters, who had no inkling that he was going to cut out the dental program, cut out the labour market programs, cut the funding for legal services, jack up the HECS charges, jack up the child-care fees and introduce tens of thousands of dollars in entry contributions for nursing homes. The government has failed battlers.

The government has also failed a lot of its own traditional constituency and supporters. We have heard a lot of talk in this budget debate about the need to support small business, a constituency the Liberal Party likes to call its own. What the government has not yet acknowledged is a growing tragedy in small business, which is suffering grievously at the hands of large businesses. Today's bankruptcy figures confirm this. Nationally, the number of bankruptcies rose by 21.8 per cent in the 1995-96 financial year, with the most dramatic rises in those states with the strongest economic growth—Western Australia and Queensland. Nowhere is the plight of small business more evident than in the large shopping centres that ring our national capitals.

The sad fact is that many small traders who choose to invest their time, energy and savings in large shopping centres are vulnerable to exploitation by unscrupulous retail managers who all too often seek to enrich themselves in an improper way and at the same time destroy the livelihood and lives of those honest and hardworking small business people.

An increasing amount of evidence demonstrates the questionable practices at work in Australian retailing. The number of owners and agents being taken to Queensland's Retail Shop Lease Tribunal for misrepresentation has increased by 40 per cent in just two years. Jones Lang Wootton's David Sylvester notes that the figures demonstrate an urgent need to increase professional standards, all the more so in those states which lack the Queensland process.

In a paper it commissioned last year, the Retailers Council of Australia found that shopping centre retailers were `easy prey' for landlords. According to the Australian Financial Review, Professor Alan Millington, who researched the issue, had a scathing view of the practices of some shopping centre landlords. The Retailers Council of Australia maintains that there is an unhealthy oligopoly or monopoly situation in Australia which provides those landlords with excessive power.

In their pursuit of higher profits, some owners and operators of large shopping centres have dispensed with ethics. They do not care how their centre's competitive edge is achieved and they are happy to employ glorified standover merchants to implement their destructive policies. I want to spend a few minutes talking to the House about the deeds of some of these people.

There is a Mr Vin Maranda, who was formerly employed by Westfield Australasia as leasing manager. In that capacity he oversaw the leasing of retail premises at Doncaster Shoppingtown. When Mia's Cafe was vacated some time ago, it was replaced by a sports store. The proprietor of this store was advised by Mr Maranda that he would need to pay some $60,000 in key money to establish his operation. That money was paid to Mr Maranda.

Like many retail tenants, this small trader found that his turnover was far less than what the retail manager had promised, so he approached the Westfield management and asked for a rent review, especially on the basis that he had already paid $60,000 in key money. The response from the Westfield management was that they knew nothing of the key money. It is quite likely that Vin Maranda appropriated this money, that it was in effect a secret commission and that it was not the first he had organised.

Earlier in his career at Doncaster Shoppingtown, Vin Maranda had dealt with the Italiano family, who in mid-1990 invested approximately $120,000 in a delicatessen. An additional $100,000 was spent by the Italiano family in refitting and stock. But 18 months later, when this centre was being expanded, the delicatessen was forced to move. This necessitated the expenditure of a further $170,000 in fitting costs.

As an agent of the owners of the centre, Mr Maranda was obliged to disclose the owner's intentions, but all the while he was dealing with the Italiano family he concealed one vital fact: that the shopping centre was to be extensively revamped and the position they had paid so much to secure would not exist in future. Sure enough, when renovations which had not been disclosed at the time the original lease was entered into began, the Italianos were moved to another location, which was disastrous for trade. The value of their business plummeted, but the rent remained the same. They were reduced to financial ruin, their last privation being forced out of the shopping centre days before Christmas when they might have at least benefited from the traditional Christmas crowds.

Mr Maranda's exploits do not stop there. As leasing manager at Southland, he insisted on a payment of $5,000 to arrange a certain position for a seafood trader. It later turned out that he could not secure that location, but he refused to refund the $5,000. The management at Southland would probably know nothing more of this than their colleagues at Westfield knew of the $60,000 key money.

Vin Maranda was quietly dismissed by Westfield after the Doncaster Shoppingtown episodes but, as far as I know, no police action has followed his dismissal. He received corrupt payments but, as far as I know, there has been no review conducted by his former employer as to the extent of his misdeeds. They might like to think he was the one bad apple. If so, they are mistaken.

I would also like to acquaint the House with a Mr David Boesley, formerly the centre manager at Chadstone Shopping Centre and thereafter the centre manager at Melbourne Central. It is a tragedy that after a lifetime of successful retailing, Nick and Val Kambouropoulos were introduced to David Boesley by a Mr Philip Akathiotis. Mr and Mrs Kambouropoulos were assured that trade at Melbourne Central was very good and that they could expect to generate up to $30,000 a week. In taking over the Terrace Restaurant, they paid $200,000 in key money and their rental was $5,000 a week. Philip Akathiotis joined their staff. Within a few weeks it become very obvious to Mr and Mrs Kambouropoulos that the trade at Melbourne Central was nothing like what had been promised. Turnover was very low, but their repeated requests for a rent review were denied.

Nick and Val Kambouropoulos were joined in their valiant efforts to save their investment by their three children, who gave up their three jobs to join them. After two years, the burden of high rents took its toll and in May last year the business closed. With it went the life savings of the Kambouropoulos family.

Meanwhile, David Boesley signed up a new cafe proprietor in a superior position on the same floor as the Terrace Restaurant. The negotiations were done behind their backs and it came as a cruel blow to learn that the new tenant was Philip Akathiotis, who until that time had been working for them. They later learned that Mr Akathiotis was being charged one‐fifth of their rental.

Mr Boesley, a low‐life retail manager who betrayed the confidence placed in him by a hardworking Australian family, left Melbourne Central under a cloud. But he has not departed the retailing scene. He has taken up a senior management position at Melbourne's Crown Casino. If his management style remains the same, Crown will be able to offer Victorians a unique double—you can be fleeced either as gamblers at the roulette table or as tenants in its retail complex.

I understand that, before he departed Melbourne Central, David Boesley was making overtures to the Kambouropoulos family about moving them into the casino. I further understand that one of his new clients will be Mr Akathiotis.

Small retailers should be extremely wary of dealing with David Boesley. He has no conscience when dealing with hardworking retail tenants and will rip them off in any way he can. Members will think it curious when they consider how much of what is questionable in Victorian business finds itself linked to the Crown Casino.

If you talk to small traders in these large shopping centres—for example, at Box Hill in the electorate of the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge)—you will be told that there is a system of graft and corruption at work within them. There is a system of favouritism. If a tenant wants to flourish, he or she will be well advised to bestow favours, in cash or in kind, on leasing managers. There exists in Melbourne shopping centres a practice of corrupt payments, both in cash and kind, to which owners are turning a blind eye. As long as they have a steady queue of new traders willing to replace those whom they force out through unconscionable conduct, the problem for the owners of large shopping centres simply does not exist.

These are not isolated incidents. They are going on all the time. This government cannot believe that there will be a recovery through small business when it will not act to protect it. It will not act to support the Leader of the Opposition's private member's bill—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gash, Joanna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in response to the budget on behalf of the people of Gilmore and on behalf of those Australians who gave us a go at the recent election. I do not believe anyone was under the illusion that this was going to be a budget of goodies for the nation. The deficit left by the previous government had seen to that. However, I believe the response to the budget by the people of Gilmore has been positive, with the constituents knowing there was a job that had to be done and being prepared to take up the challenge.

SPEECH.PARA: As a woman, I fully understand the feelings of trepidation experienced by many families in the lead‐up to the budget. The source of this unfounded fear was a campaign of misinformation by the Labor Party directed at those who feel most vulnerable in our society—the elderly and the infirm—the very same people who worked so hard to make Australia what it is today.

The basis of this campaign was that we were a government without compassion; that we were simply economic rationalists who cared about figures and not about people. In retrospect, this makes me extremely angry, particularly in the light of the success of the budget that was brought down on 20 August, a budget that has drawn praise from all quarters as both fair and honest.

With regard to our aged population, it is our responsibility to allow them dignity and provide them with the security they need and deserve. The budget has provided for this. However, an intolerable situation arose when the opposition waged a campaign of uncertainty against the aged in the wake of the budget. I refer, of course, to our efforts to overcome the deterioration of nursing home facilities.

Within the framework of the budget, there was scope made available to raise the standard of nursing home facilities through capital investment. The opposition chose to interpret and run with the line that this meant a $26,000 entry fee to nursing homes. There is no set entry fee. Yet they would not let the issue drop. As late as question time today they continued to attack and engender fear in our aged population. These were and still are underhand tactics, seeking short‐term political points at the expense of our senior citizens. Those who cannot afford to pay to enter a nursing home will not have to do so.

There can be only $2,600 per year drawn down for a maximum period of five years. Only those who can afford an entry contribution will pay one. I ask the question: is it not fair that those who can afford the expense of an outlay do so? Is it not better that we maintain nursing homes of high standard, allowing all users the same high quality accommodation as was established in the hostel system by the Labor government?

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to whip the hat around?
—Would you like to speak for a while?
—Order! The House will come to order.

—Thank you. Indeed, is it not the philosophy of the Labor Party for the wealthier to look after the not so well off? It begs the question: what were the opposition doing over the last 13 years? I do not believe that they were planning for a secure and comfortable life for our elderly, a sector of the population that will be increasing, as we all know, in future years, one that we in this House will all reach before too long.

SPEECH.PARA: This government is forward thinking. It is not out to make cheap political points. This is why the Australian people so overwhelmingly opted for change at the recent election. The recent budget also recognised that there are many people in our population who do want to work. I think everyone in this House agrees that opportunities have to be created. The difference lies in the fact that this must involve positive outcomes.

People cannot be shoved into training programs which are the whim of a government, and mickey mouse programs at that, but which bear no relationship to the needs of employers. The unemployed are not cattle that are to be moved from program to program to cook up the figures.

The Australian population demands real jobs—a fair day's work for a fair day's pay. A job that provides dignity and a sense of self‐worth for an individual is the vital ingredient to a happier and more productive society. The framework for the creation of such an outcome was again created by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) when he brought down the budget on 20 August. This government has demonstrated that it is responsible, that it can make the hard decisions and that it is prepared to take out the political cost of reductions in spending, because we are intent on laying solid foundations for the future generations of Australians. Every Australian knows that if you are earning $300 you cannot continue to spend $400 without coming to a financial calamity. As a responsible government, we are not prepared to borrow to pay our interest and ignore our immense debt.

BREAK.PARA: Gilmore is a disadvantaged area with an enormous amount of potential. It is my overriding goal to see that it goes beyond the possibilities that it possesses. The news that HMAS Albatross was to receive an injection of funding and has been earmarked for future investment was welcomed by both me and the electorate. Albatross is already a hive of activity. The knowledge that the government continued recognition of it as a key defence establishment has boosted the morale of its officers and men. Moreover, it provides the much needed stability and career advancement that has not previously been so assured.

These men and women are critical to the security of the nation's future. They recognise and respond to the knowledge that their role is of the utmost importance. They are also aware of the amount of money that the government and the Australian people have invested in them. We cannot afford to allow these men and women to feel insecure or uncertain about their positions. They are vital to ensuring the security of our nation.

I stated that my mission was to see Gilmore fulfil its full potential, and I believe the Treasurer on 20 August provided the scope for this to be achieved. Without doubt, the key element to this was the long awaited announcement of incentive for small business.

For too long employers, who will inevitably be the people and the organisations that absorb the massive unemployment in our area, were denied the opportunities they deserved. Their entrepreneurial spirit and financial investment were being restrained by an arrogant government. The previous administration had legislated to such an extent that the business community was aware that in such an environment the risks far outweighed the potential rewards.

One of the keys to establishing momentum within the small business sector and the economy as a whole will be the scrapping of the unfair dismissal law. I call on those in the Senate who hold the future of the workplace relations bill in their hands to allow the abolition of this law. It must be done in order to allow businesses to take on employees and to expand their operations, secure in the knowledge that they will not be burnt at a later date. Further to this, I must stress that fear and intimidation have no place in today's societies. The roles of the employer and the unions are changing and must continue to do so. We have to work in harmony to create jobs and wealth for all Australians.

During the election this government ran on the platform that the family would be of paramount importance, and our policies would certainly reflect this. I think it gave all members on this side of the House a great sense of pride to see this commitment carried through in full. The difficulty in fulfilling this commitment was intensified primarily by the backdrop of the tight fiscal restraint made necessary by the economic mismanagement of the previous administration.

The family tax initiative gave back to those who contribute the greatest to our society—the family. For too long they have been ignored. I commend both the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer for providing families in Gilmore and across the nation with the incentives and rewards that are rightfully theirs.

Voters across Australia made their voices very clear on the day of the election. With their votes came a plea for accountability—accountability as to where their money was going. The Australian people realised that they could no longer afford programs that had no outcomes—programs that were only being put in place for political gain. In line with this, the people of Gilmore took great heart in seeing that some of the difficult problems afflicting our area and society in general were tackled in this budget.

I note with pride the package relating to a 100 per cent increase over three years for marriage and relationship counselling. Not only is this government committed to the strong in our society but it recognises the needs of those experiencing difficulty with the trials of life, at times through no fault of their own.

This leads me to another area, again particularly poignant for Gilmore—youth suicide. The national youth suicide strategy, recognising and emphasising the particularly acute nature of this problem in rural and regional Australia, is a welcome initiative. I pray that we can make inroads into this tragic situation, one that has traditionally been brushed under the carpet.

An area arising from the budget for which I have received positive feedback is that of home and community care, known as HACC. This is of great importance within Gilmore. Many groups have welcomed the decision to standardise fees for services as both fair and just. The increase in funding of six per cent over four years for HACC has been seen by community groups as a well thought out approach to an ever increasing service and demand. Once again, this has been a very positive outcome from this budget.

May I now revert back to those who hold the balance of power in the Senate. I implore them to display leadership in allowing the sale of one-third of Telstra to go through. We were up-front with the Australian people during the election and they chose the option of implementing one of the most important environmental packages in the history of our country. I lay particular emphasis on this because Gilmore is blessed with some of the most magnificent natural gifts in the nation, the crown jewel being Jervis Bay. This package has been praised by conservationists and environmental groups throughout my electorate. We must be allowed to reap the full benefits of this momentous environmental package.

Continuing in the environment vein, I commend the government on its creation of the green corps. This innovative program is particularly pertinent to Gilmore as we have many unemployed young people who would find inspiration in being able to commit themselves for a period of time to working towards the protection and betterment of our coastline and landscape. The government providing a program of this nature shows that it is truly in touch with the mood of the people of Australia, and young people will be able to gain a qualification while maintaining some of the pristine areas within the Gilmore electorate. It is an exciting and thoughtful policy.

The qualifications that participants will receive relate to landcare management, forestry plantations, heritage protection and aspects of marine biology. However, most of all it is for our youth to learn and share in our greatest asset of all, that being the aquaculture and marine based industry. We have the perfect location for what we know will be an area of growth; that is, discovering the potential for food cultivation in our oceans.

There can be little doubt that the formulation of this budget was always going to be a difficult task. The previous government—and I refer to Mr Keating—showed considerable hypocrisy in the manner in which they left the finances of this nation. The Labor Party and its then `world's greatest Treasurer' boasted to Australians of his fiscal responsibility during the 1980s. However, this was abandoned once Mr Keating became Prime Minister in the early 1990s.

The budget brought down by the Treasurer on 20 August began the clean‐up of the financial mess left behind by the previous administration. I am very proud to be part of a government that is prepared to accept its financial responsibility without abandoning its social conscience.
