I believe the recent budget to be the first in a series of benchmarks that this government will provide to the people of Gilmore and Australia as a whole.

When I say this, I refer to both its honesty and fairness. This was reinforced by the introduction of the charter of budget honesty. The Australian people will no longer tolerate being deceived by politicians, as they were by the former Prime Minister when he told the people of Australia that the budget would be in surplus. Our charter represents the first step in re‐establishing this trust that the population should have in their representatives in government.

There is a new breed of politicians in this parliament. We may not always be politically correct, but we do believe in honesty and integrity. It is my ultimate goal to see both sides of the House take a more bipartisan approach to issues of national importance, and the economy is a case in point. I applaud the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) on his earlier remarks this evening. Opposing for the sake of opposing, without cause or conviction, is futile. Thoughtful and stimulating debate is productive. As I said earlier, the days of formal ideology are essentially over.

Gilmore should be one of the shining lights of Australia. I commend this budget on taking the first difficult step in addressing the economic and social problems that confront not only my electorate but the nation as a whole. Moreover, I commend it as a budget that showed the courage to take the initiative to return Australia to economic prosperity, which both our generation and future generations deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sercombe, Bob,MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Australians are entitled to a lot better than what the government is delivering to them in this budget. It is a budget of broken promises in a range of important areas of our social and economic life. It is a budget that sells Australia short in a number of critical areas, even in areas where the government is strong on rhetoric. It is a budget wherein substance often simply does not materialise, where the rhetoric might well have led one to expect it to.

SPEECH.PARA: The budget rips nearly $8 billion out of our economy by a savagely contractionary process that undermines the capacity of the Australian economy to grow and hence create jobs. Ironically, by choking growth—as this budget does—what is undermined is the government's rationale for so many of its measures, including its debt reduction strategy. Choking growth obviously very much calls into question the government's capacity to achieve the sorts of outcomes that it talks about.

By international comparison, Australia is well off in terms of debt, despite the rhetoric and the humbug that we have heard consistently from the government. Australia has the fourth lowest debt and the third lowest budget deficit in the industrialised world. Compare that with the legacy that was inherited by the incoming Hawke government in 1983 after John Howard had been Treasurer: in current dollar terms, the Hawke government inherited a budget deficit of $25 billion. That position was accompanied by high unemployment and an inflation rate of 10 per cent plus.

BREAK.PARA: If one compares that situation with the economic setting of the Howard government upon coming to office earlier this year, one will see that inflation is averaging at just 2½ per cent, the rate of economic growth is four per cent, 700,000 new jobs have been created over the last three years and there are increasingly diversified exports. Increasing the diversification of our trade with the rest of the world is, in my judgment, the single most crucial issue facing the Australian economy.

As I said, it is a budget of broken promises and a budget that sells Australia short in all sorts of areas. There is a lot of humbug from the government about being committed to families. To prosper and thrive, families need to have their breadwinners in jobs, but this budget is based on savage contraction in the economy and offers no hope for employment. We have seen rising unemployment in recent days. Where does that sit with the government's commitment to families?

In the health area, private health funds have taken away the value of health insurance initiatives taken in the budget. Most families with children in care will lose more than they gain from the family tax initiative. In the area of pharmaceutical benefits, we are seeing a budget that savagely slugs families. We will see an undoubted drop in the levels of bulk-billing for medical services, and associated with this are the consequences for families.

Perhaps the opposite extreme within the public's view of the Commonwealth's budget responsibilities—and let me go away from families—is the question of overseas aid. I think this government's rhetoric on this area simply does not match what the budget contains. We have heard the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) talk about 1997 being the Year of South Asia. Frankly, that is something I applaud—having recently come back from a delegation to that part of the world. That, of course, will be the subject of somewhat more report to this parliament in due course.

The government is identifying an objective for this country in relation to South Asia. If that is accompanied in this budget by savage cuts in huge percentage terms in overseas aid to South Asian countries, I just cannot see that this government, in its dealings in that area, will be able to match its rhetoric with the substance of what it delivers.

We have a government here that talks a lot about its support for business. An effect of this budget is that manufacturers will have a decline in support from government of some 60 per cent over the next three years. Exporters stand to lose $500 million over the next three years as a result of the budget.

The Metal Trades Industry Association, hardly a Labor Party front, has recently produced a report on the budget. I would like to refer extensively, if I may, to a number of aspects of that report. It states:

Very significantly, the Government has chosen to severely cut industry programs and to place a charge on imported inputs to manufacturing, at a time when business conditions are extremely difficult, with little prospect of improvement in the short term.

The National Accounts released on the day of the Budget confirm that manufacturing output growth actually contracted in the June quarter (‐1.5%), with related falls in employment and profits. To take decisions in these circumstances, across a range of portfolios, that will conservatively leave the manufacturing and construction sectors some $1.1b worse off over the next 2 years (net effect), is risky indeed. Furthermore, the decisions are particularly disappointing and puzzling given the retention of major subsidies to the mining and rural industries.

Of further concern is that many of these decisions will fall on exporters. The dollar is currently some 20% higher against the TWI than at this time last year, demand conditions are weak and uncertain, and competition in our Asian export markets is rising strongly while growth is easing. These conditions, of themselves, are making exporting so much more difficult and the Budget's prediction of weaker export growth . . . concedes these difficulties.
If the cuts indicate a weaker commitment by Government to exports of manufactures, this would be viewed with dismay by industry. The single most important achievement—
and this is crucial—

of the restructuring of Australian industry over the past decade, has been the extraordinary and sustained growth in exports of elaborately transformed manufactures. At a trend rate of about 18% . . .

The MTIA is saying that this government's rhetoric about business is simply not fair dinkum. I will just run through a few of the programs of assistance to exporters that have been slashed in this budget. They include the abolition of the shipbuilding bounty, the abolition of the Asia‐Pacific fellowship scheme, the abolition of the Asia business links program, the abolition of the Asia infrastructure consortia program, the abolition of the innovative agricultural marketing program, the abolition of the international trade enhancement scheme, the slashed funds for the export market development grants scheme, the reduced funding for the export access program, the abolition of the DIFF scheme—and I bet that is one Alex wishes he had not touched—the cut of 14 per cent to Austrade's operational budget, the cut of more than $50 million to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade's operational budget over two years, the abolition of the Market Australia program, the cut back of DFAT's international public affairs operations, the abolition of TradeBlazer, the abolition of bounties for computers and related hardware equipment—and the list does go on.

So it really is a government of considerable humbug when it talks about itself as having a commitment to supporting business in its important functions of sustaining an increasingly prosperous Australia. It is a government that also sometimes pretends it has concerns about regions of Australia. But we saw the regional development program scrapped even before the minister received a report from McKinsey, Supporting regional leadership: unfinished business, for which he was paying something like $7,000 a day. I am sure all members would be able to provide examples of very effective regional development programs right across Australia that were contributing towards Australia's economic efficiency, its business efficiency, as well as its social justice through those regional development programs.

In my own particular part of Australia, the northern and western suburbs of Melbourne—an area that, over the last decade, has faced extraordinarily difficult processes of economic restructuring associated with the new realities we find ourselves in—the regional development programs and the Commonwealth support for them have been absolutely vital in relation to the sorts of adjustments that have been required. There are three particular programs that I want to refer to which are very much under some question now as a result of the Commonwealth pulling the pin.

One such very impressive program would benefit not only the west and north of Melbourne but also surrounding agricultural areas—that is, a freight service for perishable foods. A number of business incubator programs look as if they are in some difficulty. A major program, a feasibility study of a sporting complex associated with the Royal Melbourne Show Grounds, looks as if it may have some limited future with the Commonwealth's withdrawing its support from this important area of activity.

Perhaps though, in my view, the single most damning aspect of this budget is what the government is doing with research and development programs. I believe that to be the case because what it is doing signals a government that is simply myopic, short-sighted, about what is required for the long‐term future of this country—what is required to ensure high sustainable rates of growth; what is required to achieve improvements in our trade; and what is required to make this country and its industries increasingly competitive.

The key to achieving that sort of Australia—an Australia that is competitive with high and growing incomes—is increasing emphasis on what are regarded as knowledge intensive industries: those industries that are knowledge intensive in producing goods and services, particularly in the area of elaborately transformed manufactures. I refer back to the importance that the MTIA document that I have referred to placed on that particular part of our economy.

Those parts of production represent the fastest growing areas of world trade. There are considerable opportunities in them for further growth in incomes while, at the same time, providing a stretching out of the balance of payments constraint that has traditionally operated on the rates of growth in Australia. To achieve those effects, research and development and the Commonwealth's commitment to them have been an absolute key—and this budget, in that respect, is an absolute disaster.

Last week we had the fairly shameful spectacle, I believe, of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) trying to confuse the issue by talking about tax rorts in respect of research and development syndicates. It is a bit rich even for the Liberals to be doing that when it was they who opposed so many of the changes that were introduced by the previous Labor government to iron those very things out.

In fact, the reports that were referred to specifically, I understand, by both the Treasurer and the minister for industry have been those very issues which have been picked up by Labor's checks and balances in the system. I think the minister for industry on 1 August in the Financial Review in fact conceded that when he said, `Well, they've been knocked back in the evaluation of various programs'—referring to some of those he then brought into this House and used as some sort of rationale for attacking research and development syndicates.

What this government is about is throwing out the baby with the bathwater. The reaction to that, which has been widespread, I think is instructive. Professor Sir Gustav Nossal, probably Australia's most eminent scientist, is quoted in the Australian on 27 August as warning that Australia's future—and he puts it that strongly—has been:
. . . jeopardised by the federal Budget cuts to tertiary education and incentives for research and development.

A string of press articles has appeared about the devastating impact of the government's decision to cut back the R&D tax concession and abolish the syndication arrangements on this country's capacity to position itself for higher growth—higher growth in those industries of elaborately transformed manufactures and knowledge intensive services which are so important to us in the growing areas of world trade.

Mr Deputy Speaker, let me perhaps give you some examples of the sorts of programs and some specific programs that will not be available as a result of what this government is doing. JNA Telecommunications Ltd is a company in Melbourne that is expected to generate about $60 million internationally and $30 million domestically over the next three years. That particular company was the beneficiary of syndicated R&D. SCITEC, another Melbourne company, is a communications systems supplier that employs 176 people. An investment in R&D of about $17 million was syndication financed at a time when the company was severely capital constrained. There have been discoveries related to AIDS by a syndicate involving the McFarlane Burnett Centre, the New South Wales Blood Bank and the Amrad Corporation.

These are the sorts of vital initiatives which we need for our country's future but which this government, through its so cavalier treatment of the research and development industry resulting from this budget, is taking from us. This is against the context of the Liberal policy statement on science where they actually said:

. . . changes to the syndicated research and development tax concession guidelines may well result in the drying up of one of the few effective forms of venture capital available in Australia to fund research and development.

What absolute hypocrisy on the part of this government to adopt that in their policy going into the election but then for us to find that they treat the issue in such a cavalier way when they come to power.

Let me restate the importance of some of these issues. Business research and development trebled as a share of gross domestic product in the decade to 1993-94. There was a sharp rise in that decade in the research and development intensity of Australian manufacturing. There has been powerful evidence from academic studies of a link between increasing business research and development and increased exports. Australia undoubtedly is very competitive internationally in its capacity to do research and development.

We have the Bureau of Industry Economics in 1994, on the syndicated research and development scheme, reporting that syndicated R&D is a uniquely Australian and uniquely successful means of providing government support to building high-tech businesses. Despite the government's rhetoric about tax rorts, that particular BIE report found that the syndicates had a high rate of inducement of R&D, with about $2.60 of additional R&D induced for every dollar of research undertaken by participants which would have gone ahead anyway. The BIE study concluded that the syndication program can be seen as `a unique and highly effective instrument for cheaply stimulating new R&D'.

Across that whole range of areas, we see cant and nonsense being talked by the government; we see a myopic short-sightedness in relation to this country's future. The area I do want to stress is that so much of this country's future—its capacity to grow, stimulate jobs and be competitive—is in that area of value adding to knowledge intensive areas.

With not only this government's actual cutbacks to research and development programs but all that that signals to companies who have a range of choices as to where they may locate those sorts of activities—whether they locate them in Australia or elsewhere—what this government's lack of commitment indicates is, I think, quite devastating for the outlook and the economic future of this country. I believe that this is a budget that deserves to be roundly condemned.

SPEECH.PARA: What is desperately needed is a thorough inquiry into the administration of justice. A parliamentary inquiry with all the powers of a royal commission would be better than Caesar judging Caesar. For a whole variety of reasons, I have little faith in Commissioner Falconer. The area of special investigation should centre on ex-Commissioner Bull, his Deputy Commissioner Ayton and the man who said he was the only one he could trust—the Director of Public Prosecutions, John McKechnie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace, Elizabeth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to bring the House's attention to the recommendation by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee for subsidy of betaferon for the treatment of patients with relapsing and remitting multiple sclerosis. This is very welcome news for people with multiple sclerosis. The approval of betaferon for listing will make a difference to thousands of MS sufferers, the vast majority of whom are unable to afford unsubsidised access to this treatment.

SPEECH.PARA: One such sufferer wrote me a very passionate letter asking for my support for listing of betaferon. Her letter touched me and reinforced my opinion that this drug should be listed as soon as possible. She writes:

I was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis 2 years ago. At that time I was informed of a drug Betaferon which was being developed to combat the disease and since then I have monitored closely the progress of this drug.

As you no doubt understand, I have awaited the introduction of the drug into Australia with much excitement and anticipation. Knowing there was hope certainly made it easier for me to survive the past couple of years.

I am only 23 years old. Two years ago I ice‐skated for Queensland and represented Australia in my sport. I was fit and active, enjoying all the things 21 year olds enjoy. Revelling in the fact that I was young and alive. Now I cannot walk for more than 15 minutes per day (stumbling most of the way and with 90 year olds overtaking me). Now, only 2 years later, I feel like an old woman.
I would not wish to have anyone experience what I have been through and what I continue to endure daily. Nor would I wish to see a close friend or relative suffer from the disease.

However, my greatest fear is that, because Governments have no personal experience with the disease, the people who have the power to decide whether Betaferon is listed do not really know or appreciate multiple sclerosis's misery.

Over the past few months alone I have experienced a severe attack in my right leg, a milder attack in my left leg and a loss of strength and co‐ordination in my right hand. With every nerve that is damaged, I wonder whether this is it. Has the disease turned chronic and am I to progressively deteriorate, at an unpredictable rate?

Sometimes the nerve will rebuild itself and I will breathe a sigh of relief—but only to wake up the next day with another attack. I have been on a rollercoaster for the past 2 years and I still don't know whether the trip from here is all downhill. At the risk of sounding melodramatic, the feeling is (I am sure) akin to being buried alive.

With the listing of Betaferon I have a chance to reclaim my life. But every day that goes past my chances are slowly being taken away from me. If I am given that chance, I have much to contribute to society. I am in my second year of articles with a big inner city law firm and will finish my law degree at the end of this year with first class honours. I will also finish an economics degree by the middle of next year.

I have experienced more than many people will in their lifetime, and I have grown strong. I want to use what I have learnt and the strength that I have gained to contribute to society. The alternative, if Betaferon is not listed, is that I become increasingly reliant upon society to support me because of my illness. I am sure that I don't have to do the sums for you.
I understand that the government, like anyone, has only limited funds to go around. But please don't tell me my life is not worth $18,000 a year.

Betaferon should be listed on the PBS on moral, ethical and on pure economic terms. The initial expense is justified if you consider that without the drug I will most likely have to live off welfare for a significant proportion of my life.

Secondly, at my age, this drug is a cure. It will significantly reduce the number of exacerbations that I will suffer from; accordingly it will stymie the cumulative force of the disease and significantly reduce the risk of permanent disability.

I beg the Government to do the right thing and ensure that Betaferon is listed. Research for a more effective drug or even a complete cure continues, with the benefit of knowledge obtained from the development of Betaferon. But, in the meantime, please do not take away my chance to lead a happy and fulfilling life. I really do think I deserve one and I will repay society many times over.

Hers is a truly inspirational story. I look forward to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee's favourable recommendation and to seeing that this important drug is listed on the PBS schedule as early as November 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to talk about the future of the textile, clothing and footwear industry. It is an industry of particular importance in my electorate of Batman, which is in the northern suburbs of Melbourne. In doing so, I must say that I was quite `underwhelmed' to recently read in a piece of PR bumph sent to me that the coalition Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, the member for Ryan, Mr Moore, has given strong support to the TCF industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Ryan recently chaired the first meeting of the TCF Advisory Board. Unfortunately for the industry, that meeting was held prior to the coalition budget. Many people in the industry, both employers and employees, were stunned by the budget decision to abolish, without any full and proper consultation, the unique and important labour market adjustment program set up for TCF workers.

The key role of the TCF Advisory Board, which involves employers and employees as well as the government, is to improve consultation. The minister chaired that inaugural meeting of this important board promoting consultation. But here we have an important initiative of the government—the TCF labour adjustment program—abolished without any consultation, without any concern for the needs of those workers in the industry who have worked long and hard over very many years.

The labour adjustment program was created in recognition—and we should not lose sight of this issue—of the fact that many workers in the industry would lose their jobs because of government trade policy, the opening up of Australia's trade barriers in association with international globalisation of the Australian economy. It has to be noted that they would lose their jobs through no fault of their own. The great majority of these workers—those to be assisted by the program—are those with low levels of education, migrant women of non-English‐speaking background and outworkers.

The TCF labour adjustment program provided wage subsidies for up to 18 months so as to ensure that those workers who were dislodged as a result of the restructure in the industry had an opportunity to enter relevant training and, if need be, to get assistance with relocation.In my electorate of Batman, over the last four months more than 400 TCF workers have lost their jobs because of the massive changes that are continuing to occur in the industry. Just half of them would have been eligible for the special TCF labour market adjustment program.

I also note that this program just does not assist my electorate. Around the nation more than 1,500 workers in the industry have lost their jobs in the last four months. If the labour adjustment program had continued in this budget, more than half of these people, who are predominantly women, would have been eligible for support under the scheme.

In South Australia—the home state of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone)—some 38 people who lost their jobs at a clothing factory called Protector Safety and at a footwear factory called John Firth and Sons could have been eligible for the labour adjustment program. In Minister Moore's home state of Queensland, where the TCF industry is not very strong, some 15 people who lost their jobs in June from a clothing factory in Brisbane called Freedman Pty Ltd could have been assisted. Twelve of these people were eligible without a doubt for the special adjustment program.

In central Victoria, where I recently visited, one former TCF worker who had benefited from the labour market adjustment program broke down when she questioned me about what would happen to other workers in the region. With the closure in recent weeks of Holeproof in Horsham, over 100 workers will similarly be denied assistance as a result of this budget decision.

I consider that there is an onus on all of us to assist these workers. These people's low levels of skills give them little hope of getting a new opportunity in life. Now, because of the abolition of the labour market adjustment program, they have little hope of getting the finances to assist them if they desire to relocate. For example, Clarks Shoes in my electorate is to relocate from northern Melbourne to the suburbs of Adelaide.

I say in conclusion that it is high time the Liberal government revisited its budget decisions. Some workers out there in industries such as the textile, clothing and footwear industry demand special assistance. They demand it because they are losing their jobs through no fault of their own. There is an obligation on the Australian community to go out of our way to ensure that, as we open up the Australian economy to international competition, we do everything possible to assist those workers. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Entsch, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the House tonight to give recognition to a dedicated group of young Australians currently forging a name for themselves in my electorate and, undoubtedly, eventually nationwide. This is happening at a time when the youth of our nation—especially our indigenous youth—are coming more and more under the spotlight of review and when multiculturalism is under attack. I was delighted last weekend to officiate at the opening of an event that I feel sure will become a featured model of just what can be done when indigenous people are led by people of their own culture who have drive, vision and dedication to the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Cairns is fortunate to have amongst its many fine community groups one that shines out above the norm. Tribal Colours of the Pacific is the vision of one very dedicated young man, Mr Aquilar Luki. He brings together indigenous youths from various Australian and South Pacific backgrounds in an enjoyable and learning environment that both celebrates their heritage and gives them pride in their roots.

Tribal Colours of the Pacific is founded on a drug free concept, with all of the youths involved being alcohol, drug and tobacco free. These concepts are projected through the group's cultural performances in song and dance. With ages ranging from 10 through to 26 years, Tribal Colours of the Pacific now boasts some 40 dancers based predominantly in Cairns, but also with some dancers studying at universities in Toowoomba and Canberra. The group works very closely with the police and citizens youth clubs around Far North Queensland.

The group reflects Far North Queensland's exceptionally diverse indigenous cultural base, as it currently comprises 11 Aboriginals, 11 Torres Strait Islanders, three Papua New Guineans, four Samoans, two Tongans, one Tahitian, two New Zealanders, two Niuans, one Fijian, two Cook Islanders and one Solomon Islander. It is a very diverse group but one that both performs superbly and mixes magnificently because of its base of a celebration of common linked cultures.

All members of Tribal Colours are taught arts, crafts, song and dance from various cultures of the Pacific, studying under older tutors from the various islands who now live in Cairns. But the hard work and dreams of Aquilar Luki and his supporters do not end there. Their eventual aim is to emulate the success of the world famous Pacific Cultural Centre in Hawaii, where students from all over the Pacific live on campus in their own university dividing their studies between modern professional skills as well as the relearning of the unique cultural skills of their parents, grandparents and great‐grandfathers.

Anyone who has witnessed the daily afternoon shows conducted through the various South Pacific villages of Hawaii's Pacific Cultural Centre will surely agree that the dreams of Aquilar Luki and his Tribal Colours group promise to be one of the most exciting concepts ever offered in Australia to indigenous youth. Their own university will give them equal emphasis on professional qualifications as well as preserving their own unique cultural heritage. Such a facility not only will become one of Cairns's major tourist attractions but will provide an absolutely unique avenue for upper secondary and tertiary education on campus for all of our Pacific people who have made Cairns and Far North Queensland their home.

BREAK.PARA: If anyone here doubts the attraction of well-organised and well-presented indigenous cultural events, last weekend's inaugural Pacific Cultural Festival—held at the Cairns Police and Citizens Youth Club—was sold out weeks ahead of the event. The magnificent display of cultural music and dancing, combined with a veritable smorgasbord of traditional dishes, was the resounding success that it and the hard work of the people and kids of Tribal Colours well deserved. Not a single person who attended, including me, walked away from that evening without being deeply touched and enriched by this wonderful experience.

I would like tonight to commend Aquilar Luki and the youths of Tribal Colours of the Pacific and their supporters who made this first ever Pacific Cultural Festival the success it was. With people such as these leading our indigenous groups, instilling self-esteem and hope for their future, it fills my heart with pride to see the dedication to both the future and the past that is being encouraged amongst our indigenous youth—and all without the pervading influence of the drug and alcohol culture that we often associate with modern youth. Tribal Colours of the Pacific goes on its annual non-profit Queensland tour at the end of this month. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier tonight I observed that, as a result of the recent budget, it is abundantly clear that the ethos of this government is that, if you cannot pay, you miss out. There is evidence of this in a range of areas—home and community care, dental treatment and nursing homes, to name a few. Another area where this ethos can be found is in relation to access to the information super‐highway via the Internet for all Australians.

PARA.BREAK: Regrettably, the recent actions of the government in this vitally important area have not received much attention. In the budget, the Howard-Costello government has pulled the plug on access to the Internet for all Australians through public libraries. As part of the Creative Nation program, the previous Labor government paved the way for all Australians to have the opportunity of access ing the information super highway by linking public libraries to on-line services such as the Internet.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor government provided $11.4 million to link all 1,400 public libraries around Australia at a cost of about $7,000 each. This was a small price to pay to ensure that all Australians would have access to these services. The decision recognised that the rapid advances in information technology had the potential to create a new form of discrimination between those who could afford access and those who could not.

The development of a new form of disadvantage between the information rich and the information poor should be a matter of grave concern to all of us as legislators. The victories of the 19th and 20th centuries to ensure equal access to educational opportunities for all have to be protected. Access to the information superhighway should not be denied on the basis that a person cannot afford to buy the equipment. But this is exactly what will happen as a result of the policies of this government. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has pulled the plug on the Internet at public libraries. The budget cut $9.2 million out of the program. One suspects that this is everything that was not already spent. This is bad policy.

It is surely also bad economics to restrict the access of one part of the community to information services and associated opportunities on the basis of their bank balance. There are areas of public policy into which this mean‐spirited ethos of `if you can't pay, you miss out' must not be allowed to intrude. Access to information technology is one of them.

In this context, I was greatly concerned by the story in the Computer Age of today suggesting that universities may soon have to pay for access to the Net. Are we heading for a modern version of 18th century Britain where only the rich could read—a return to when basic education was denied the poor as it was felt that this might lead them to question their place in the social order? Australia goes down this path at its peril.

For the constituents of Scullin the Labor government's initiative would have built on the development of on‐line services being undertaken at the time by the local regional library service, the Yarra Plenty Regional Library Service. I congratulate this regional library service for their initiatives in this area. It is regrettable that the federal government has shown that it lacks the same breadth of vision. Thanks to the Prime Minister, in the area of public access to Internet—as in many other areas—many of the constituents of Scullin are being effectively told by the federal government, `If you can't pay, you miss out.'

In the same vein I note, and indicate my disquiet, that not only do we see in the budget papers a lack of commitment to the extension of the Triple J network—which, according to the budget papers, is to achieve a saving of $2.5 million over four years—but also there is another line item which indicates there has been a cessation of the radio Triple J Internet site, J Net, which would save $2.1 million over three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Those that say, `Hear, hear!' have to realise that, for the younger generation—if not for all Australians—the Internet will become more and more important as a source of information. If we choose to be blind to that, we do so at our own peril. We see the commitment that there is to Triple J by young people in Australia. If a network like Triple J could be extended by such a project as J Net, I think it deserves our support. Whilst I know that there are those on the other side who would have us wipe Triple J right out of existence, I do not think that that is a very good policy. I think that there should be a continued commitment to the expansion of Triple J, either by extension of its radio services or by its venture into J Net.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise tonight to talk about some of the small, micro and medium sized businesses in the electorate of Dunkley by the bay. There are about 8,000 such businesses, many of them run by sole proprietors. These people run shops and service delivery agencies. They are often busy during the day with customers and clients. They spend their evenings—rather than watching question time—doing their paperwork.

There are other so-called business people out there who make a living from preying on these honest small business proprietors and their employees. One such scam was brought to my attention last night by an operator of an excellent gift shop in the suburb of Mount Eliza in my electorate. This scam, which was brought to my attention by Cynthia Fewster, who runs this gift shop, was quite disgraceful. I need to bring it to the attention of the House and many small business proprietors.

One lunchtime while Mrs Fewster was looking after a number of customers in her shop the phone rang. She answered the phone and the voice at the other end addressed her by her name and read out a recent advertisement, almost word for word, that she had placed in one of our local newspapers, which she believed was the Frankston Flier. That is a local fortnightly publication. A similar ad had appeared in a number of the other local Frankston and Peninsula newspapers.

BREAK.PARA: The caller asked Mrs Fewster if she would like to advertise in the Federal Environmental Journal. Not unnaturally, Mrs Fewster was in a bit of a hurry to get off the phone and get back to making some money from her customers, and she gave a fairly indeterminate answer. The persistent caller said that most people gave their birth date as a reference number. This was not to send Mrs Fewster a birthday card but to send her, in the next few days, what looked like a bill.

When the call was finished, Mrs Fewster did not think much about it. But shortly thereafter a fake invoice arrived for $289, being the supposed cost of an advertisement covering one‐eighth of a page of this journal, which I might mention is not known to anyone in the minister's office, is not recognised by anybody I speak to, but is allegedly being published somewhere up on the border between Queensland and New South Wales. The invoice curiously stated that there is `no claim made on this charge'. I wonder whether, if we were to challenge the proprietors about this paperwork—which, incidentally, has no ACN number on it—they would say, `It is not really an invoice. It might be a quote or something.' I am not quite sure what the line would be.

Mrs Fewster also got a thankyou from the advertiser stating that the publication would contain much needed information on environmental matters as well as editorials by councils, government departments and the like. It further stated that, if she were to pay her account within 14 days of the booking, she would receive a discount.

A couple of days later a courier company arrived at her doorstep complete with a reply paid courier satchel for the cheque and a mock‐up of this so‐called journal. The invoice and the thankyou note carried an address at Mudgeeraba, which is on the Gold Coast. Mrs Fewster was smart enough to refuse to pay the money over.

Upon checking, we found that the business name was registered to a Robina, Gold Coast address under an Australian company number—which we also pursued—which was a shelf company registered somewhere else in Queensland. The person behind the company was a Ms Little.

To cut a long story short, Ms Little was also registered under the business name of the Federal Environmental Journal but at a different address. The address that is provided has no such business there; it is vacant. It is above the electorate office of my friend and colleague the member for Richmond (Mr Anthony). There is no such journal being published that we can establish. This scam is going on to take advantage of hardworking, busy small business people in my electorate and throughout the country. The proprietors are preying on these busy people, hitting on them to pay for sham advertising.

I recommend that proprietors be wary of these advertisers, who are trying to exploit the high level of sales competition and the heavy workloads of many people operating small businesses in our country. If you do happen to come across a copy of the Federal Environmental Journal, be very careful about it, and certainly do not pay for an advertisement.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Alice Springs to Tarcoola Rail Line

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 21 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the estimated value of the Alice Springs to Tarcoola rail line.
(2) How would its transfer to a private or public sector operator impact upon the financial statements of Australian National.

(3) Will the Government provide direct or indirect assistance, other than the transfer of the Alice Springs to Tarcoola line, to a private firm or firms or State and Territory governments to construct a rail line between Alice Springs and Darwin.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian National Railways Commission (AN) has advised that the written down replacement value of this line is $256,360,000. The written down book value is $106,300,000. However, the AN Track Access Unit advises that the earning potential of the line implies a market value somewhat less than these figures.

(2) AN currently owns and maintains the line. The National Rail Corporation (NR) operates freight trains over the line, for which it pays AN a fee. AN itself operates only the Ghan passenger train over the line. If the line were transferred to an Alice Springs‐Darwin railway operator, AN would lose the income stream from NR (and any other operator who might choose to operate trains to Alice Springs) and be relieved of the cost of maintaining the line. AN would need to pay an access fee to the new owner for Ghan operations.

However, the Government is committed to establishing a new organisation to own and maintain the interstate rail network. This could include the Tarcoola‐Alice Springs line. Thus, AN may not continue to own the line in the longer term, but would continue to operate the Ghan over it for a fee. This is the same position that AN would be in if the line were transferred to a developer who constructs and operates the Alice Springs‐Darwin line.

(3) The Government believes that the private sector is the key to the construction and operation of an Alice Springs to Darwin line, and will facilitate any economically viable proposal for private enterprise to construct the line. In addition to providing the existing Tarcoola‐Alice Springs line to a private developer prepared to build and operate an Alice Springs‐Darwin railway, the Government would also consider tax issues as they affect the viability of the line. The project would be eligible for infrastructure bonds if assessed by the Development Allowance Authority to meet the necessary criteria.

If the offer of the Alice Springs to Tarcoola line were not taken up by the time the proposed interstate track authority is established and other interstate track transferred, the Alice Springs‐Tarcoola track might also be transferred to the track authority. However, it could be transferred to new ownership at a later time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 17 June 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Australia Council's Literature Fund determined that core funding will be restricted to publications with a circulation of 1000 or more; if so, (a) when was the determination made and (b) why was it made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. Under the Council's `Program Grants' program, magazines with a minimum circulation or sales of 1000 copies per issue, distributed nationally and devoted entirely to Australian creative writing, or with 10,000 copies distributed free of charge per issue, are eligible to apply for core funding grants for a three year period. Foundation grants for completely new magazines, devoted predominantly to the publication of Australian creative writing, are also offered under this program.

In addition, under the `Commissions' program, certain magazines with a minimum circulation of 500 copies sold per issue or 10,000 copies distributed free of charge per issue are eligible to apply for fees to literary contributors (but not for core funding).
(a) The determination was made in November 1995, for applications in 1996.

(b) The Literature Fund assists literary magazines as a means to an end—the publication and promotion of Australian writers and writing. The Fund considers that it is more likely to achieve this objective if literary magazines are encouraged to increase circulation and hence the potential audience for Australian writers.

As part of its normal evaluation process, in 1994 the Literature Fund employed a consultant to evaluate its Literary Magazines Program. The evaluation recommended, as a means of encouraging increased circulation, that the minimum eligibility figure for core funding be lifted from 500 copies subscribed/sold to 1000 copies.

Over 1995 the Board consulted with literary magazines editors, publishers, writers and other interested parties on the proposed revisions to its literary magazines funding program. Following analysis of the views put forward and further discussion, the Board developed the new ways of funding magazines referred to above.

The Fund believes that the 1000 copies minimum eligibility level for magazines applying for core funding is not onerous or unrealistic. The majority of magazines that are funded have subscriptions/sales that exceed this threshold. Moreover, in some cases magazines may have had more than 20 years of substantial funding from the Council in which to reach that circulation threshold.

Furthermore, there is an alternative means of funding for these magazines with a circulation between 500 and 1,000. Grants of between $10,000—$20,000 will be given to magazine applicants under this program to help them attract work by new and established writers. This alternative is also designed to increase circulation—by encouraging the commissioning of writers the Fund expects that the magazines will be able to attract more innovative material that will appeal to a wider audience.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tuckey, Wilson, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 24 June 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Aboriginal Land Councils exist in Australia.
(2) Where is each located.
(3) What total revenue do Aboriginal Land Councils derive from (a) the Commonwealth, (b) State governments, (c) mining royalties and (d) other sources.
(4) What procedures for reporting financial details apply to Aboriginal Land Councils.
(5) What proportion of the sum referred to in part (3) has been spent on the health, education and housing of persons whom Aboriginal Land Councils claim to represent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is extremely difficult to provide an exact figure for the number of Aboriginal Land Councils that exist in Australia. Some are established by Commonwealth and State legislation. Other Aboriginal organisations with the term `land council' in their title have been incorporated under relevant State legislation or the Commonwealth's Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976. ATSIC does not fund all such bodies, nor is it aware of the budget details of all such bodies. From the information available to it, ATSIC has identified 140 land councils.
(2) Attachment A provides the locations of these 140 Aboriginal Land Councils.

(3) (a) The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) can provide precise information on funds that it provides to land councils. In the case of the Land Councils in the Northern Territory established under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 (NT Land Rights Act), ATSIC can also provide precise information on statutory royalty equivalent payments from the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account (ABTA).

74 statutory and non-statutory Aboriginal Land Councils received $37,655,054 in funding from ATSIC in the 1995-96 financial year. In addition, aggregate statutory royalty equivalent payments of $27,193,122 were made to the Northern Territory Land Councils from the ABTA according to ABTA financial statements for the year ended 30 June 1996.
(b) Information on the total revenue that Aboriginal Land Councils derive from State governments is not available to ATSIC.

(c) In relation to mining in the Northern Territory, an equivalent amount to mining royalties received by the Government in respect of mining on Aboriginal land is paid into the ABTA by the Commonwealth. The NT Land Rights Act provides for the payment of monies from the ABTA for the administrative purposes of the Land Councils established under the NT Land Rights Act and distribution to royalty associations and communities. As mentioned above, the total revenue Aboriginal land councils derived from mining royalties in the form of statutory royalty equivalents payments under Subsections 64(1), (3) and (7) of the Land Rights Act in the Northern Territory in 1995‐96 was $27,193,122.
Information from State Governments on the total revenue Aboriginal Land Councils derive from mining royalties in those states where mining may have taken place on Aboriginal land is not available.

(d) Apart from information in respect of the Land Councils established under the NT Land Rights Act, information is not readily available on the revenue that Aboriginal Land Councils derive from other sources. Based on Annual reports tabled in Parliament, Land Councils in the Northern Territory received self-generated operating revenues from other sources in 1994‐5 as follows:
Northern Land Council—$35,488; Central Land Council—1,005,443;
Anindilyakwa Land Council—13,410; Tiwi Land Council—38,451

(4) Extensive reporting of financial details is required of ATSIC grant recipients including Aboriginal Land Councils. The four statutory Aboriginal Land Councils in the Northern Territory have additional requirements as Commonwealth Statutory Authorities.

For grants from ATSIC, the Land Councils are required to provide audited financial statements and a certificate signed by the Chairperson of the Land Council stating that the grant funds have been used for the agreed purpose and that all terms and conditions of the grant have been fully and properly complied with.

In the case of the Land Councils in the Northern Territory, as statutory authorities of the Commonwealth, the Land Councils provide reports annually to the Parliament, including audited financial statements. Aboriginal Land Councils established as statutory authorities under State legislation report to the relevant State Parliament.
(5) ATSIC provided grants totalling $4.8 million to Land Councils in 1995‐96 for health, housing and education.
The principal functions of most land councils are not directly focussed on health, housing and education.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government undertaken to halve the paperwork and regulatory burden on small business; if so, will the undertaking be achieved during the life of this Parliament.
(2) Did the undertaking relate to (a) Commonwealth, (b) State and (c) local government paperwork and regulations.
(3) What proportion of the paperwork and regulatory compliance burden on small business can be attributed to (a) Commonwealth, (b) State and (c) local government requirements.

(4) Is the paperwork and regulatory compliance burden on small business being benchmarked and its reduction monitored: if so, (a) by whom, (b) what methodology is being used and (c) will the impact of Government decisions which increase the administrative burden on small business be included in benchmarking and monitoring.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 2 May 1996, the Prime Minister announced the establishment of the Small Business Deregulation Task Force. The Task Force is required to report to the Government by November 1996 on revenue neutral measures to reduce the paper and compliance burden on small business by 50 per cent within the first term of the Government. The Task Force is on schedule to report by 1 November 1996.

(2) The undertaking relates essentially to Commonwealth regulation, but the Task Force has been asked to make an assessment of the interaction with State and local government business regulation and compliance requirements and in cooperation with the States, look more broadly at the overall regulatory environment. At the National Small Business Summit held on 12 June this year, all governments agreed to work with the Task Force to reduce the paperwork and compliance burdens imposed on small business. In addition, Small Business Ministers agreed to meet later this year to discuss the recommendations of the Task Force.

(3) The Task Force has commissioned research to identify the paperwork and regulatory compliance burden on small business. The preliminary findings of the research concludes that in general small business does not distinguish between the three spheres of government when assessing the burden. Yellow Pages was engaged to undertake a national survey of small business in order to identify a national benchmark of the compliance burden. The results of this research will be available in mid‐September.

(4) The National Small Business Summit agreed to exchange information on the development of benchmarking and compliance cost assessment to enable governments to measure their performance in reducing the burdens placed on small business. The Task Force is expected to make some recommendations in this area.
